Thanks you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging timeWe value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Dear First Minister,I write to you as chairperson of the Rest and Be Thankful Campaign, a group which represents more than , Argyll businesses.Over the past few weeks, we have twice written to Cabinet Secretary for Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity Michael Matheson and sadly received no response.Regarding the Rest and be Thankful , whilst we welcome the decision to select option one for the permanent solution of the landslide-blighted section of the A, we fear a further consultation simply delays the process # the phrase #kicking it into the long grass# springs to mind. Especially when option one, the Glen Croe route, was the chosen option from the A Trunk Road Study # summary report published by Jacobs in .Surely, after nine years of consulting, the Scottish Government and Transport Scotland can choose the best solution rather than going through a y and expensive consultation process.Based on this, our members would like the permanent solution fast tracked, which is well within the Scottish Government’s power and we would ask for this to be seriously considered.Our other comments and feedback to last week’s announcement are as follows:The timber road route should be upgraded as a short-term solution this summer and not in the suggested  months.Argyll businesses have faced the issues of landslides for many years. However, the situation has worsened over the past year and in our opinion it has now become a national emergency and requires immediate action.The , tons of unstable material could swamp any further mitigation measures put in place on the A and Old Military Roadand make the roads impassable. This could easily happen when we next have an extended period of rainfall.Savings in further mitigation work could go towards upgrading the forestry road.The long-term solution should be selected from the  The A Trunk Road Study and based on the delivery of the most sustainable outcome.Any well-developed permanent solution needs to be open  without fear of being buried under tons of rock and mud, and will have less environmental impact than the landslides, catchpits, netting and OMR bund we are currently experiencing.Our understanding of costs and timescales from similar schemes in Norway show a tunnel could be built in three years at a cost of £-m, and not the £-m stated by Transport Scotland.Members of The RABT Campaign group represent a cross section of business sectors and we would welcome the chance to meet with your officials to discuss how we might help cut through the y timescales and fast-track decision making.John Gurr  Sir,I heard that there was work going on in Lochgilphead town centre, and that some people were complaining, about mess and upheaval. No change there then!When I observed the work, I was so surprised at the dference this will make to the town and to the moaners I say #you cannot make an omelette without breaking eggs#.When I spoke to them, the workforce were polite and commented that they were looking forward to the end result.For too long now Lochgilphead has been the Cinderella of Argyll and Bute now it seems she will go to the Ball.From a very satisfied resident.Name and address suppliedSir,Just ahead of WWF’S Earth Hour last year, the country was put into lockdown due to the Covid- pandemic. As we look ahead to this year’s event on Saturday March  at .pm, many of us are reflecting on the future, as we emerge from the latest, and hopefully last #stay at home# period.With that in mind, we are asking people to use Earth Hour by helping us to create the #Great Scottish Canvas#. Switch off your lights and by candlelight or torchlight, use the hour to paint a picture, craft a poem, doodle or write something which illustrates the future Scotland you want to live in.With so many eyes on Scotland this year, due to Scottish Parliament elections in May and the vital COP climate talks in November, we want to show the world the vision of the Scottish people, for a greener and fairer society for us all. Find out more at the www.wwf.org.uk website.I look forward to seeing the things you believe will make Scotland a better place, perhaps changing the way we heat our homes, how we travel around our towns and cities, or even how we grow the food we eat.Lang Banks, director, WWF Scotland, EdinburghSir,Tuesday March  marked the anniversary of the day the UK entered lockdown. We have lived through what is probably the most extraordinary year in most people#s letimes.Blind and partially sighted people have had to adjust, like everyone , to the daily challenges this  has created. Thankfully, there#s now light at the end of the tunnel. But some ongoing measures could continue to be barriers to their independence and confidence.People with sight loss can sometimes find it dficult to judge space, so we’re asking everyone to maintain their own distance, be patient and be helpful.Just getting out and about can be more hazardous for those without sight. The government#s #Spaces for People# initiative has already transformed many of our streets and thoroughfares. We must take care that this doesn#t inadvertently create new obstacles for those with disabilities.Let#s make one positive legacy of this crisis a resolve to make sure we re-emerge as a society in which no one is left at the margins.James Adams, director, Royal National Institute of Blind PeopleScotland, Edinburgh

title: coronavirus-sfa-suspends-lower-leagues-amid-rising-cases
story: SCOTLANDS lower league football fixtures have been postponed for three weeks due to the rising number of coronavirus cases.The suspension will affect Gala Fairydean Rovers and Vale of Leithen who play in the Lowland League as well as Peebles Rovers, Coldstream, Hawick Royal Albert United and Eyemouth, who compete in East of Scotland isions.In a statement, Scottish FA chairman Rod Petrie said its board had decided to cancel all football beneath the SPFL Championship for the next few weeks.He said: ldquoThe Scottish FA is well aware of the efforts all clubs take to comply with the exacting protocols that were conditional on elite football being given an exemption to continue amid the pandemic.ldquoNone the less the continuation of football at all levels has weighed increasingly heavy on me as President, my colleagues on the board and the Joint Response Group as we have watched the new strain of the virus spread rapidly.ldquoWhile the national sport has been afforded the privilege of elite sporting exemption, the risk of mass transportation of untested, largely part-time players is something that cannot be sustained as the cases continue to rise and available hospital beds become increasingly scarce.ldquoAfter discussions with the SPFL, the Premiership and Championship will continue on the proviso that both adhere to the existing testing regime."The vast majority of teams in those isions are full-time professional clubs and so the risk of transmission remains manageably low."The cost implications to lower-ision clubs was one factor but so too the realisation that many ndash with some notable exceptions ndash consist of part-time players who are either prevented from working due to the virus or have to work.ldquoIn either case, the risk is currently too story: DARCY GRAHAM is set to start against Wales on Saturday as Scotland look to make it two wins from two in this yearrsquos Six Nations campaign.Gregor Townsend saw his side record an historic victory at Twickenham last weekend, with Scotland running out - winners to take home the Calcutta Cup.However, the victory has taken a toll on Townsendrsquos side, who will be without three starters from last weekend due to injury when they face Wales at BT Murrayfield on Saturday .Jamie Ritchie , Sean Maitlandand the impressive Cameron Redpathwill all be forced to watch the game from the sidelines.:Ex-Borders rugby player named farmer of the year in UK awards ceremonyThe injuries have opened the door for Borderer Darcy Graham to go from the start. story: LITTER is a blight on our towns and villages, and although many heroic groups regularly clean up their communities with mass events, the pandemic has rubbished those large gatherings.Yet rather than moan about the selfishness that shames the Peeblesshire countryside, locals are getting their hands dirty to keep the streets clean.Simon Ritchie has launched a network for local volunteers who want to go out litter-picking in their own time, at their own pace, in a COVID-safe manner.This month he joined an online Peebles Community Council meeting to tell members about the Facebook group he has launched ndash Keep Peebles Clean.He said: ldquoLast March, I spent a lot of time at home and I noticed there was a lot of litter everywhere."Today, I was in the Quadrangle, and I noticed bags and packets were floating about in the wind at the War Memorial.ldquoIrsquom not interested in just articulating the problem or moaning about it or apportioning blame ndash we all recognise therersquos a problem and I want to act."There are a lot of groups and iniduals in Peebles already tackling litter, but I know itrsquos not been possible over the last year because of the pandemic and group gatherings are to be avoided.ldquoBut I also know there are a lot of people quietly getting on with it in their own time without any attention or support, and to my knowledge, theres no single group dedicated to litter picking year-round in Peebles, in the same way we have Bonnie Peebles Plus for flowerbeds.Mr Ritchie said he wants the eco volunteers to feel like their good work is valued.ldquoI would like to provide iniduals with the kit that they need ndash litter grabbers, disposable gloves, high-vis vests, strong refuse bags."I want them to feel that their work is noticed and celebrated, as it should be, and I want to digny their efforts with decent equipment."Explaining that he has already contacted a major fast-food chain asking for funding, Mr Ritchie added: ldquoI appreciate therersquos a cost to providing this equipment and Irsquove already approached McDonaldrsquos."I donrsquot knowyoursquove noticed the provenance of some of the litter around the town but some of it, especially in the lay-bys, is from McDonalds."On the basis that they are a multi-billion pound company that produces a lot of waste packaging, Irsquove told them we are looking for about pound to get started up to buy the kit.Andthat funding bid isnrsquot successful, Mr Ritchie says hersquos willing to crowdfund and put his hand in his own pocket.The plan going forward is to make contact with Scottish Borders Council regarding the collection of the litter and to establishinsurance is required.ldquoLike most people, I hate bureaucracy with a passion," said Mr Ritchie."My strong preference is for an informal network of people, who are co-ordinated via WhatsApp or Facebook, and who do the work at their own risk and sign a disclaimernecessary.ldquoHowever, I acknowledge that the constitution of such a group is not my area of expertise and I dont want to fall foul of the law."My only ambition is that people that want to pick up litter can do it efficiently, effectively and safely.Chairman Les Turnbull said the community council would be delighted to support the project and would be willing to lend volunteers the appropriate equipment.The Peebles Community Trust also gave its support, with chairman Lawrie Hayworth saying he would welcome a conversation around public liability insuranceit is required.Meanwhile, the streets, grass verges and parks in Innerleithen are looking much better thanks to residents.Earlier this month,members of the community carried out their second litter pick.Dawn Derbyshire told the Peeblesshire Newsthat the litter collected was ldquostaggering. She explained: ldquoIn all, about  large bags were filled with potential for much, much more."One picker retrieved  dumped plastic water bottles along a stretch of road which appear to be from one serial litterer as they were all the same brand and size.ldquoThere are many iniduals that do this kind of thing, quietly, all the time just whilst they are out walking, so a big shout out to those too.ldquoWith such enthusiasm to keep the beautul place where we live clean and litter-free, we are hoping to grow the event and include other groups in a possible annual event."Visibility is key, as is education, so we would hope to involve the local childrenpossible but its early days. Watch this space.As the war on litter wages on, residents in Peeblesshire arenrsquot just talking the talk, theyrsquore walking the walk... with a litter picker and a bag in hand, determined to do their part to keep the communities they live inclean.

title: coronavirus-peeblesshire-test-sites-operate-next-week
story: THREE places in Peeblesshire will be among the next Borders sites offering tests to people without coronavirus symptoms.On March , NHS Borders announced that new community testing centres would be rolled out across the region.And on Tuesday , the health board revealed that fire stations in Peebles, Innerleithenand West Lintonwill be offering tests next week.:Heroin offences: Peebles man sentenced after admitting pair of drugs crimesNHS Bordersrsquo director of public health, Dr Tim Patterson, said: ldquoThe more we know about COVID-and where it currently is the better able we will be to contain it and limit its spread throughout our communities.ldquoAlthough cases in the Borders are low at present, there are still cases out there. We are specically trying to identy the  per cent of cases in which people do not experience the typical COVID- symptoms.ldquoThis is why we are particularly interested to offer testing to people who regularly come into contact with others such as those who provide care to family or friends or those who work in essential sectorsand do not receive regular testing through another route.:Peebles man: Ive asked McDonaldsthey can fund litter-picking equipmentThe West Linton testing site will open on Monday , offering tests until Tuesday.Meanwhile, testing in Peebles will be available from Tuesdayuntil Thursday, with tests in Innerleithen on offer between Wednesdayand Thursday.Tests will take place between .am and pm at the venues, with people able to book ahead by emailing ATS.Service@borders.scot.nhs.uk or calling  .:Coronavirus: Borders continues streak of days without new cases being recordedElsewhere in the Borders, testing has been taking place at Eyemouth, Coldstream, Lauder, Duns and Galashiels this week, with Selkirk offering tests over the weekend.Next week, Newcastleton will be offering tests between April  and April .Meanwhile, testing will again be available in Hawickand Jedburghndash with testing centres having already opened previously in those towns.

title: drink-driving-hawick-woman-four-times-legal-alcohol-limit
story: A BORDERS woman who went for a drive to Galashiels while four times the legal alcohol limit has been banned from the road for two years at Selkirk Sherf Court.Lauren Dryden, , from near Hawick,pleaded guilty to driving in Abbotsford Road, Galashiels, during the early hours of March  with a breath alcohol count of  microgrammes - the legal limit being .Procurator fiscal Fraser Matheson said that at about .am police officers on patrol carried out computer checks on a vehicle and decided to pull it over.He added they detected a strong smell of alcohol and felt Dryden was over the limit.:Borders driver failed to give second sample of breath at police stationShe gave a positive reading and she was arrested and was taken to Hawick Police Station.Mr Matheson said she co-operated with the toximeter test and recorded the reading of  which was almost four times the legal limit.Defence lawyer Colin Severin said the mother-of-two had been suffering health issues in recent times.He explained: "She had been drinking wine at home and decided to go for a drive as it would calm her down.:Heroin offences: Borders man sentenced after admitting pair of drugs crimes"She advised that she immediately exited the vehicle when she saw the police and said she had been drinking."She hopes to never find herself in this situation again."Dryden, of Cavers, near Hawick, was fined pound and ordered to pay a victim surcharge of pound.She was banned from driving for two years but was offered a chance to sit the Drink DrivingRehabilitation Course whichcompleted at her own expense would result in a  per cent discount in theof the disqualication period.

title: face-mask-rules-scotland-mandatory-coverings-eased
story: Face coverings have become a part of everyday le as people quickly adapted to the coronavirus pandemic.Since June, wearing a covering has been mandatory on all public transport in Scotland.A month later, it became law in shops.But as Scotland looks towards an exit from lockdown ndash with First Minister Nicola Sturgeon outlining a route map to Level  earlier this month ndash it raises the question: how much longer will we have to wear masks Here, we outline when other countries have eased their mandatory mask policies, and what has been said so far in Scotland.What is going on where In Australia, the state of Victoria eased restrictions on Friday meaning masks will no longer be mandatory in retail settings.They will, however, need to be worn on public transport, hospitals, care homes and taxis.People will also have to carry masks with them, and are being urged to wear them when physical distancing is not possible.It comes after  days without any local cases of the virus there.Elsewhere, in New South Wales, masks will no longer be mandatory ndash including on public transport.The state has recorded just two cases of community transmission in the past two months mdash both linked to the states hotel quarantine programme.Chief medical officer Kerry Chant said the restrictions were beingscrappedon the basis that there was nocommunity transmission of Covid.Given that Scotland has also introduced a mandatory hotel quarantine scheme, it could be hoped thatlocal community transmission can be reduced to similarly low levels, then we could eventually follow suit in mask policy.In America, despite President Joe Biden making it clear restrictions are still necessary, the state of Texas has ended its mask requirement.Mississippi has also followed suit. However, health experts are warning the pandemic is far from over there, with cases likely to pick upcurbs were lted too soon.What  has been said about masks Passengers will be asked to wear face masks on Ryanair flights potentially until , the airlinersquos boss has said, as he announced ato a more normal summer schedule.The budget airline plans to run around , flights every day during the summer this year, Michael OrsquoLeary said.ldquoI would imagine at this point in time, wersquore planning to continue to require mandatory face mask wearing on board our aircraft through the remainder of this summer schedule and next winterrsquos schedule, Mr OrsquoLeary said.What do we know so far in Scotland According to the Scottish Governmentrsquos website, ldquoin all levels and settings, we should follow ldquoadvice and requirements such as on the use of face coverings.Speaking on March  when she outlined Scotlandrsquos route map out of the pandemic, the First Minister said that it is ldquohoped that we could reach ldquoat least Level  by the end of June.Currently, guidance under Level  includes the mandatory wearing of face coverings on public transport and shops ndash unless you are exempt.However, Ms Sturgeon said that ldquowe hope we will be able to get beyond even that, with a ldquoview to restoring as much normality as possible.Wersquove shared our timeline for a safe and gradual easing of restrictions in Scotland.All dates are dependent on scientic evidence that it is safe to ease further.Watch our video to find out more ##Read the timeline ## https:t.co XabMrdBXjtpic QoVbuyaXVmdash Scottish GovernmentMarch , She told MSPs: ldquoIt is our fervent hope - and also our tentatively increasing expectation - that vaccination, continued and effective use of the test and protect system, and probably a continued compliance with precautions like good hand hygiene, will allow us to keep Covid under much greater control.ldquoAnd that this will allow us to enjoy many of the things that we took for granted before the pandemic ndash for example, normal family gatherings where we can hug our loved ones, sporting events, gigs and nightclubs.She said that she is ldquooptimistic this date will be over the summer, adding ldquohopefully something closer to actual normality, with the ability to hug those we love, will become possible.What does this mean From this, we can establish that the wearing of face coverings is likely to be in place for some time yet.The First Minister has pointed towards ldquoactual normality by some point in the summer, suggesting thatthe science backs things up, there could be a potential relaxation of the rules around masks.However,we look towards the decisions being made in Australia, the levels of cases may need to get to extremely low levels for this to take place.

title: walter-scott-prize-2021-shortlist-announced
story: THE five books shortlisted for the Walter Scott Prize for Historical Fiction  have been announced.The shortlisted entries are:The Tolstoy Estateby Steven ConteA Room Made of Leavesby Kate GrenvilleThe Mirror and The Lightby Hilary MantelHamnetby Maggie OrsquoFarrellThe Dictionary of Lost Wordsby Pip WilliamsEach shortlisted author will receive pound, and the winner will get pound,.Award judges ndash Katie Grant , Elizabeth Buccleuch, James Holloway, Elizabeth Laird, James Naughtie and Kirsty Wark ndash said: ldquoFor the first time in the history of the Walter Scott Prize, Australian authors comprise the majority of our shortlist.ldquoWith imaginations and styles as ied as they are inspired, we have Pip Williams slipping us gently, hauntingly, into the Oxford English Dictionary Steven Contersquos unflinching weaving of war and peace in the shadows of Tolstoyrsquos estate and Kate Grenville expertly stitching the unreliable but compelling testimony of the remarkable Elizabeth Macarthur into an exploration of the meaning of home.ldquoAnd asthis wasnrsquot riches enough, we are launched so vividly into Tudor England with Hilary Mantel and Maggie OrsquoFarrell that we live and die ndash what a death! ndash with Cromwell, and die and live, through a heart-crunching transformation, with Shakespearersquos son Hamnet.ldquoIn short, the  Walter Scott Prize shortlist isnrsquot just a masterclass in writing, it offers readers five experiences theyrsquore unlikely to forget.The winner will be announced in June in an online event. The prize was first awarded to Hilary Mantelrsquos Wolf Hall in . Other former winners include Andrea Levy and Sebastian Barry.

It was brilliant that people in Glentress rolled up their sleeves to work with us ndash it meant the economics stacked up and they were not left behind.ldquoDemand for services in Glentress has been spectacular, with almost everyone already opting for an upgrade to make the most of their new high-speed network.ldquoFull fibre is the next generation of internet technology and this latest upgrade will transform peoplersquos internet experience. Residents can check online to seetheyrsquore now able to upgrade and should contact their service providers to find out about switching.:Stunning Peeblesshire mansion has outstanding apartment for salePeeblesshire residents also vocally welcomed the upgrade, which is part of a pound billion plan to reach up to  million UK premises by the mid-to-late s.Stewart Maguire, of Glentress, said: ldquoWith two of us working from home during the pandemic and my two sons doing home-schooling lessons on their iPads, we desperately needed high-quality and reliable broadband.ldquoNow that Openreach has installed fibre wersquore on full gigabit and itrsquos night and day with how things were before ndash we can easily balance multiple conference calls and gaming updates at the same time.ldquoThe Openreach team were brilliant, kept the community updated throughout and catered to the requests of each of the  or so houses on the hill side. title: endometriosis-innerleithen-woman-life-condition
story: A BORDERS woman has shared how the last  years of her le have been affected by endometriosis.First diagnosed with the condition when she was , Mary Anne Willow knew she was unwell when she got her first period when she was .ldquoI can still recall my first period ndash the day of the week, when it was happening, what was going on, said Mary Anne, , of Innerleithen.She added: ldquoThe reason [for remembering] I think is because of the pain. I just put it [pain] down to periods ndash thatrsquos what periods were like.ldquoI was  years old, it was a Saturday morning, I was due to go ice-skating and I had this horrendous pain and I thought lsquothis is it, this is what your periods are likersquo.ldquoThe word endometriosis, Irsquod never heard of it. We didnrsquot have access to the internet then, as we do now.:Peebles parents hope specialist treatment in USA can help determined young sonMary Anne initially went to see her GP about her pain, which would cause her to faint and vomit.She was told by her pharmacist that she needed a prescription.Endometriosis is a condition where lining, similar to that of the uterus, forms in other areas of the body.Mary Anne explained that her experiences of endometriosis include weakness in her bowel and bladder, excessive bleeding, chronic pain, fatigue, and infertility.In  her bowel herniated and during surgery Mary Anne was given a surgical mesh implant.:A cave explorer who has travelled the world will soon talk to a Borders audienceBut the mesh was later excised after a scandal erupted in  when a British Medical Journal review revealed  manufacturers sold mesh implants with no clinical trials.Having spent four decades battling the disease, Mary Anne shared how endometriosis affected dferent areas of her le, including her school years and her career.ldquoI can remember teachers coming in [to the bathroom] and dismissing it [the pain and heavy bleeding], said Mary Anne. ldquoNo one bothered to take notice of what was going on. I was just seen as a wild schoolgirl who was trying to get herself out of lessons.ldquoIt can present employment problemsyoursquore needing time off work. It can lead to poor performance because yoursquore not feeling well, yoursquove got pain, yoursquore tired.ldquoYou can be seen as the unpredictable employee, unreliable employee ndash I had that to deal with as well.:NHS Borders ordered to apologise to patient over mental health careMary Anne shared that although she is now menopausal, the condition still affects her daily le in many ways.ldquoThings are starting to calm down, but itrsquos been  years, said Mary Anne.ldquoI still have the bladder and bowel problems. Irsquom very aware of where I go or what I do because I need access to toilets and sometimes thatrsquos not possible ndash and during lockdown where public toilets have been shut I find myself in dficult situations and that can lead to being embarrassed or humiliated.After reading a recent article in the Peeblesshire News, when the paper spoke to another person with endometriosis, Mary Anne said: ldquo[After reading] I felt sad without sounding like Irsquom patronising them. I just hope it doesnrsquot become as traumatic as it has been for me ndash emotionally and physically.Mary Anne recalled a surgical registrar ahead of her first surgery saying: ldquoThis is a terrible disease ndash itrsquos not cancer but itrsquos like cancer because itrsquos invasive and it spreads. And people do not take this seriously, it can affect other organs, other systems.:Ultrafast internet available in Peeblesshire as engineers make good progressHowever, Mary Anne is keen to highlight that endometriosis falls on a scale and is graded in its severity ndash some with the condition experience no pain at all.March is Endometriosis Awareness Month, and Mary Anne credits her own desire to help others for her courage to speak out about her personal experiences.She said: ldquo[Endometriosis] is unseen, itrsquos not a broken leg or a broken arm, itrsquos invisible. For me, I struggled not being believed. I think thatrsquos one of the hardest things to deal with, when you feel yoursquore not being believed.ldquoIrsquove found the courage to be able to share and itrsquos because I want to try and help others appreciate what itrsquos like living with it [endometriosis] or living with someone that has it, or they know of someone.

title: lowland-league-gala-fairydean-rovers-finish-6th
story: GALA Fairydean Rovers could be about to record their highest-ever finish in the Lowland League with a sixth-placed position.The league has been unable to get the go-ahead from the Scottish Football Association to resume playing after the season was put on hold in January due to increasing coronaviruscases nationwide.Declaring the season null and void would mean that the Lowland Leagues top team would not be able to go forward to the play-offs to try and earn a place in Division Two.Board members are now set to discuss a proposal to call a halt to the league and use a formula ofaverage points per game to calculate the final league positions for the  clubs.As things stand, Kelty Hearts would be champions and would compete in the play-offs with Brora Rangers, with the winners then playing the bottom team in Division Two.Using the average points formula, Gala would leapfrog Stirling University into sixth position which would be their highest-ever finish since the introduction of the Lowland League in .East Kilbride would be runners-up,with Bonnyrigg third, followed by BSC Glasgow, East Stirlingshire and then Gala Fairydean Rovers.The relegation issue - with Vale of Leithen currently pointless at the bottom - has still to be resolved and is due to be discussed at the board meeting.Gala chairman Ryan Cass said:"We will have to wait for the outcome of the meeting to see what is happening."Butthe league is settled by an average of points-per-game then finishing sixth - with our playing budget compared with other big-spendingclubs in the league - is a great achievement."However I am personally disappointedthe league does not resume because I feel we could have finished even higher."The league stopping could not have happened at a worse time for us because the team was playing well having recorded a deserved win at Boness and narrowly losing to Annan Athletic in the Scottish Cup in a game we could easily have won."Manager Neil Hastings and his coaches have done a tremendous job and built a team playing a brand of football that the town can beproud of."If the league is called off now then we would just have to accept it and then start preparing for next season when hopefully restrictions are lted and we can get spectators back at our games."The majority of the squad have re-signed for next season and there will be some new faces coming into the squad as we want to continue improving and challenging at the top of the table."

story: Nicola Sturgeon has provided an update on coronavirus lockdown restrictions in Scotland.The First Minister, joined by chief medical officer Dr Gregor Smith and national clinical director Jason Leitch, addressed the nation on some key changes in the coming days.Nicola Sturgeon said that "because of the progress weve made - both in suppression and vaccination" she was able to confirm the easing of some restrictions.Here, weve pulled together the important bits of information you need to know.Here are the key points from todays announcementlsquoStay at homersquoFrom Friday, April , the ldquostay at home order in Scotland will be ltedand replaced with a request for people to ldquostay local.Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoThe stay at home rule is being replaced for the next three weeks at least with a requirement to stay local.ldquoThat means the current travel restrictions, which prevent non-essential travel outside your own local authority area, will remain in place for another three weeks.ldquoI fully understand how frustrating that is for everybody ndash I share that frustration ndash like many of you, my family live in a dferent local authority to the one I live in, and so like anyone with loved ones in a dferent part of the country, I desperately want to see them in person.Hairdressers and some retailFurther easing of restrictions in Scotland will go ahead from Monday, Nicola Sturgeon has confirmed.Barbers and hairdressers will be allowed to reopen, along with more freedoms for non-essential retail and an increase in students in college ing to in-person teaching for practical subjects.The First Minister announced the change earlier this month, but confirmed it would go ahead at the coronavirus briefing on Tuesday.Shops will be allowed to open for click and collect services, along with homeware shops and garden centres.The First Minister added: ldquoWe donrsquot want big crowds at these stores, so although they open from Monday, think about whether you really need to visit on Monday oryoursquore able to wait until later in the week.Figures in the right direction"Were also seeing, and have seen over the past two or three months, progress in terms of the suppression of the virus," Ms Sturgeon said."Were now averaging  new cases per day. That is a decline of more than three-quarters since early January. The number of deaths from Covid has fallen even more sharply than that, which is likely to be an effect of the vaccination programme."The number of deaths is down by more than % in the past two months. As you can see from the figures weve been reporting in recent days, the number of people in hospital and receiving intensive care is also reducing."However, the First Minister said at the coronavirus briefing people should still be ldquohyper-vigilant.ldquoThere are still no grounds for complacency, she said.ldquoIn fact, it is really important right now that while the vaccination programme continues to be rolled out, that all of us remain hyper-vigilant in how wersquore going about our daily lives.The number of new cases is now ldquoplateauing, the First Minister said, having consistently dropped throughout January and February.Vaccine newsScotlandrsquos vaccine rollout has been ldquobetter than we could have dared hope for, Nicola Sturgeon has said.By Tuesday morning, almost . million people had received their first dose of the vaccine, while almost , people have been given a second dose.Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoThese figures confirm the very good progress in the last three months.ldquoThe progress in the vaccination programme is,anything, better than we could have dared hope for back at the turn of the year.The First Minister said that virtually everybody in the over- age group has now received a first dose of the vaccine.She added that % of  to -year-olds have had the vaccine, % of  to -year-olds, and % of  to -year-olds.The latest cases:Scotland has recorded  deaths from coronavirus and  positive tests in the past  hours, Ms Sturgeon said.It brings the death toll under this measure ndash of people who first tested positive for the virus within the previous  days ndash to ,.Giving a Covid- update, the First Minister said , people have now tested positive in Scotland, up from , the previous day.The daily test positivity rate is .%, down from .%.Of the new cases,  are in Lothian,  in Greater Glasgow and Clyde, and  in Lanarkshire.There are  people in hospital confirmed to have the virus, down nine in  hours, and  patients are in intensive care, up one.

Scotland Starts Here campaign and promote the wealth of experiences on offer across the region.ldquoTourism is a force for good andmanaged responsibly, sustains communities in every corner of title: vaccine-passports-scotland-nicola-sturgeon-addresses-certificate-proposals
story: Nicola Sturgeon has said that the use of vaccine certicates to allow a further easing of lockdown restrictions ldquois possible.Politicians and health experts are studying the potential use of the ldquovaccine passports, whichcould see access to venues granted onlycustomers have been jabbed, received negative tests, or developed antibodies through past infection.Currently, Israel is the only country with a nationwide pass. There, those with a digital app ldquogreen pass are given exclusive access to gyms, hotels, theatres and concerts .Asked about the idea of vaccine certicates for both international and domestic use, the First Minister said it is something that ldquoshould be considered".Speaking at a media briefing in Edinburgh, Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoIn general terms I agree that it should be looked at.ldquoI think we should consider how we use some sort of vaccine certication to open up more in the future.ldquoWersquove got to be careful and considered about how we do that.ldquoThere are still some questions that we still donrsquot fully know the answer to about the vaccine and its impact on transmission ndash although the early data on that is all very positive.Whatrsquos stopping the process Ms Sturgeon said there are ldquobig ethical questions about the certicates.She added: ldquoThere are some people who canrsquot get vaccinated for medical reasons, for example, so we need to think through all this.ldquoThe Scottish Government is thinking about it and we are participating in the international and UK-wide work on this as well.ldquoSo, itrsquos not something that I think is practical right now, but in the future it is possible and I think it is important that we give it proper and due consideration.ldquoWersquove already had some four nations discussions around this so wersquore all thinking through these things in the same way.A further cautious easing of lockdown has been confirmed in the latest review of measures.Stay Local will replace the Stay at Home rule from Friday  April, and more retail services will be able to open from Monday  April.Read full details # https:t.co apvBgDYEdpic GXQqYNYLnmdash Scottish GovernmentMarch , Worldwide approach National Clinical Director Jason Leitch told the briefing that a worldwide approach, led by the World Health Organisation, could be the best way to go about the plans.He said: ldquoI donrsquot think this is as easy as it sounds at first hearing. It is enormously complex.ldquoIt has inequalities challenges, it has challenges around those who are unvaccinated like children.ldquoThe private sector is beginning to do some of this, so some airlines are saying you canrsquot fly without a vaccination, so we will have to take a view.ldquoOur advice will be the most comfortablethe world does it, andthe WHO lead that thinking for us.ldquoThen, across the four UK countries, the clinical advisors will give the best advice we can to the four governments.

title: galashiels-academy-display-boards-show-new-school-options
story: EXHIBITION boards have been put up in Galashiels to show the potential options for the new community campus.Scottish Borders Councilhas installed the signs at the towns Transport Interchange.The boards, which form part of the wider online public consultation, show details of the five possible options to replace GalashielsAcademy.Among them is the local authoritys preferred option, which involved building part of the ,-plus pupil school in Scott Park.Carol Hamilton, Scottish Borders Councils executive member for children and young people, said: ldquoThe Galashiels Community Campus will be a focal point for the local and wider community in years to come, and itrsquos important during this consultation that we reach and receive feedback from as many people as possible."COVID- has meant wersquove had to adapt our consultation and take it primarily online, but we understand not everyone will have internet access.ldquoThese graphics boards give a full overview of all the proposals and mean we can reach all parts of society to gather their views and ensure the full-range of feedback is received.The council has posted videos and interviews online as part of the consultation.Since its launch on March , SBC says the website has recorded more than  unique visits, with visitors spending an overall total of  days,  hours and  minutes on the site.It can be viewed HERE.

title: galashiels-upper-langlee-flats-replaced-109-homes
story: GALASHIELS is set to get more than  new houses after planning permission was granted by Borders councillors this week.Scottish Borders Councilrsquos planning and building standards committee met on Mondayto discuss the development at Upper Langlee.The application ndash put forward by Waverley Housing Association to lsquoregeneratersquo its housing stock ndash will see the demolition of existing properties on the north of Beech Avenue, to the east of Laurel Grove and west of Larch Grove. The flats will be replaced by  homes.At the meeting, Galashielscouncillor Andy Anderson said: ldquoItrsquos an area that has been getting a bit tired.ldquoWe donrsquot want to replace an eyesore with another one. What we have is a lovely modern take on what was there.:Coronavirus: Borders health chief gives warning as lockdown rules about to easeMr Anderson, of the SNP, added: ldquoTherersquos a very active community there. I think once they start decanting people from there, quite a few of them want to move back.Residents of the flats set to be demolished will be offered a place in one of the new properties, developers say.The development consists of  blocks of terraced houses which ldquoinclude a range of townhouse, terraced house and cottage flats.Developers say the project will result in the felling of up to  trees ndash a move described as ldquoregrettable by SBCrsquos principal planning officer, Barry Fotheringham.According to the report put to councillors, the projectrsquos benefits outweigh the felling as ldquothe tree removal helps to facilitate the regeneration of an existing affordable housing scheme.Helen Laing, an SNP councillor for East Berwickshire, said: ldquoI think wersquove got some good sustainability proposals in this development ndash the solar  and air source heat pumps ndash but Irsquom sad to lose the trees.:Borders map reveals our driving has changed since new mph speed limits came inRegarding the development on the whole, Ms Laing added: ldquoItrsquos clearly an improvement on what is there at the moment.Fellow East Berwickshire councillor Jim Fullarton, of the Conservatives, said he would like to see the houses painted with ldquowarm colours.ldquoBalamory might be a bit much for Galashiels, but we need warm colours to fit in with the landscape. I donrsquot think there should be more than two houses of the same colour together.Mr Fullarton added that he was happy to be getting ldquorid of the blight of s architecture by replacing the flats with the new houses.Jedburghcouncillor Scott Hamilton said: ldquoSome of the buildings there were of their time. Well I certainly think that time has expired.The Conservative member continued: ldquoItrsquos a very positive project going ahead here. This project can be a catalyst to support that area going forward.:Disgrace: Vale of Leithen furious after Lowland League ends on points averageKelsocouncillor Simon Mountford, chairing the meeting, asked for the developer to consider placing charging points for electric cars in the parking area.Mr Mountford, of the Conservatives, described the proposed housing as a ldquohuge improvement on the current flats, predicting that it would be ldquoan attractive and popular place to live in Galashiels.ldquoItrsquos an echo of the pre-existing building without being a replica, he said.Councillors unanimously approved the application, subject to a number of planning conditions.One of those conditions is that the proposed residential units will have to ldquomeet the definition of lsquoaffordable housingrsquo.

title: innerleithen-bike-shop-opened-excited-gordo-hodge
story: STARTING a new business in the middle of a pandemic is dficult, but with an increasing demand for bikes and cycling equipment since the nation went into lockdown last year, it was the perfect time for one Borders entrepreneur.Since , Gordo Hodge has been providing an uplting experience for keen cyclists, through a bespoke shuttle service to downhill mountain bike routes in the Tweed Valley.Gordo wanted to build on the sell-out success of Adrenalin Uplt, which currently brings more than , riders to the valley.This month he has embarked on a new biking venture by opening the doors to lsquoThe Bike Shoprsquo in Innerleithen.He told the Border : ldquoI decided to open lsquoThe Bike Shoprsquo due to one of the other bike shops closing in Innerleithen, and as an area we need to deliver the best possible service to visitors and locals.ldquoWhen I heard that the old allotment post office building was coming up, I thought it was the ideal location and that we could make it look nice.ldquoThe name is really an lsquoit does what it says on the tinrsquo idea. We already have lsquoThe Uplt Cabinrsquo so thought lsquoThe Bike Shoprsquo was fitting.Gordo says he seized the opportunity to create more employment for the team and is delighted with the shoprsquos makeover.ldquoWe have had to be clever with space, so have a system in place where we have one of each product on display and stock other sizes and bikes which we can see quickly on an iPad, sosomeone canrsquot see it, we still probably have it.ldquoSaying that, starting a bike shop during the pandemic has proven a fun challenge with obtaining stock, but the team have done really well getting the shop refurbished, looking awesome, and stocked.Gordo Hodge. Photo: Helen BarringtonThe shop will focus on sales of bikes, clothing and accessories, but the wheels are in motion for biking trips and a glass of bubbly.ldquoWe have demo bikes and a hire fleet of specialised mountain bike, e-MTB and e-gravel bikes. More stock of bikes from other brands is on its way, as are kidsrsquo bikes, said Gordo.ldquoIt will also promote new exciting services from Adrenalin Uplt with guided rides for all types of riders, with things like Adventure e-bike, both mountain and gravel rides, where visitors and locals alike can rent the e-bike or use their own, and we will drop off with the buses and trailers down the valley.ldquoThey will then be guided back into location by our lsquoRide with a Local Teamrsquo. This can be on half-day and full-day with picnics... and maybe even a little prosecco!Launching a new business during this crippling time for the economy hasnrsquot worried Gordo too much, as the bike market has shot up since lockdown last year.ldquoThe Tweed Valley has seen an increase over the past few years, andthat last unlock is anything to go by, the area is going to be super busy with staycations for riding bikes and other outdoor activities, said Gordo.ldquoAfter the last lockdown, I would say we have seen around a  per cent increase of new riders to the area.ldquoSome brand new to riding and some were rejuvenated from past years.Speaking about the official opening of lsquoThe Bike Shoprsquo, Gordo added: ldquoI am super stoked how it has finished, and it was great to see support from local people when we opened at the weekend [weekend of March ]."Irsquom super excited to see what the team will do when we come out of lockdown.

title: aldi-join-sainsburys-announcing-new-ban-uk-stores
story: Aldi has announced a ban on plastic straws for its own-label drink cartons, the budget supermarket chain has announced.Aldi will join Sainsburyrsquos in providing paper straws which will save more than  tonnes of non-recyclable plastic each year. All own-brand drinks will now come with a paper straw thatrsquos fully recyclable and made from FSC-certied cardboard.The move is one of many packaging changes Aldi has introduced as it looks to halve the amount of plastic packaging it uses by the end of .Richard Gorman, Plastics and Packaging Director at Aldi UK, said: ldquoRemoving plastic straws from own-brand drinks cartons is another step in our journey to reducing plastic packaging across our products.ldquoOur customers want environmentally-friendly products, and plastic straws are one thing, in particular, that people want to move away from to help make a dference.The change follows a similar move announced by Saisburyrsquos earlier this week.The supermarket chain announced it will no longer sell own-brand lunchbox juice cartons with plastic straws.The company says a total of . million plastic straws will be removed from circulation each year, equating to a . tonne plastic reduction.Claire Hughes, Director of Product and Innovation at Sainsburys, said: ldquoAs we work to reduce, reuse, replace and recycle plastic packaging, wersquore committed to trialling and testing innovative new packaging alternatives for our products."She added: "Removing . million straws from circulation each year is a huge achievement and brings us closer to our goal.ldquoLooking forward, we will continue to work closely with our suppliers, manufacturers, customers and other retailers to reduce the amount of single use plastic across the supply chain, whilst also investing in research and development of materials and technologies.ldquoWe look forward to listening to feedback from our colleagues and customers about this latest packaging move.Aldi will now join Sainsburyrsquos and other supermarkets in eco-friendly initiatives as Waitrose announced it had ditched plastic from its magazines.Other recent initiatives from the German supermarket brand include the removal of plastic packaging from its entire egg range in England and Wales and switching plastic shrink-wrap on multipack soft drinks cans to cardboard.Aldi is on track to have all product packaging reusable, recyclable or compostable by the end of .

title: major-change-coming-shops-scotland-today
story: A major change is being introduced to every shop in Scotland from today.The change, which has been welcomed by a leading environmental group, will see the charge for single-use carrier bags double from p per bagto pIt comes after the initiative was backed by MSPs earlier this year.According to Friends of the Earth Scotland, in the first year after the charge was introduced in October , there was a % reduction in the number of plastic bags given out, preventing the use of  million bags.Sarah Moyes, the organisationrsquos plastic and circular economy campaigner, said: ldquoPlastic bags are a vivid symbol of our throwaway culture and this small change will help to further reduce the number of plastic bags which end up littering our streets, burning in incinerators or sitting in landfill for hundreds of years.ldquoThe huge success of the charge so far in cutting plastic waste shows the importance of targeted Government action in protecting the environment.ldquoThe plastic industry opposed these moves but time has once again shown them to have been in the wrong.ldquoThe Scottish Government recently published its draft regulations on banning single-use plastic and oxo-degradable plastic products, eg plastic straws, cutlery and drink stirrers.ldquoHowever, the launch date for the Deposit Return Scheme for drinks bottles and cans has been delayed again until July . This is despite the Deposit Return Scheme being announced in the  Programme for Government.ldquoIn order to fully tackle Scotlandrsquos plastic crisis, we need the Scottish Government to move quickly to bring forward further action including the forthcoming ban on environmentally harmful single-use items like plastic straws, plates and cutlery.A previous Scottish Government consultation found % of Scots supported increasing the charge to p.Environment Secretary Roseanna Cunningham told Holyroodrsquos Environment Committee in February that the change had been delayed due to the coronavirus pandemic.She said: ldquoWe have already affected a massive change in the use of these carrier bags.ldquoWe know there are very signicant benefits, we have seen them already, and I would imagine we will go on seeing them.ldquoIt had been our intention to lay the regulations in the first half of last year, but of course the legislative timetable had to be reconsidered in the light of the legislative requirements arising out of the pandemic.

title: alasdair-hutton-named-legend-brisbane-state-high-school
story: A BORDERS-BASED author and narrator has become a lsquolegendrsquo at a school in Australia.Alasdair Hutton OBE ndash who writes and narrates the Royal Edinburgh Military Tattoo ndash moved to Australia following the death of his father in .During his stay Down Under, Mr Hutton attended Brisbane State High School where he is now being added as one of its lsquolegendsrsquo to mark the schoolrsquos centenary.Describing the achievement as ldquoa huge honour, Mr Hutton said: ldquoI was not a distinguished student but the experience was of immense value.ldquoThere were boys and girls from all over Europe, east and west, in my classes and I was able to see Scotland from a much wider perspective than I could at home and to understand Europe much better.:Borders map reveals our driving has changed since new mph speed limits came inThe induction ceremony for the new legends will take place on July  ndash although Mr Hutton does not think he will be able to attend.ldquoI think, to my great regret, it is highly unlikely that I shall be able to be there for such a proud moment, he said.Mr Hutton ndash who was a convener at Scottish Borders Council and a South of Scotland MEP, as well as a TA Parachute Regiment officer ndash says he is ldquostunned to be on the list of lsquolegendsrsquo.ldquoWhen I look at the list which includes a governor general of Australia, Olympic gold medallists, rugby internationalists, leaders of industry, science and the arts, I am stunned to be counted in their company, said Mr Hutton.The lsquolegendsrsquo ndash of which there are currently  ahead of the induction ceremony ndash have been chosen by the school to motivate current students.

title: uk-not-fully-prepared-pandemic---dr-jenny-harries
story: The UK was not fully prepared for a pandemic of this type, Englandrsquos deputy chief medical officer has said.Dr Jenny Harries said more testing would have been carried outtests were available earlier on, and knowledge about asymptomatic transmission could have resulted in a prompt recommendation to wear masks.Speaking at the launch of the new UK Health Security Agency , of which she is chief executive, Dr Harries told BBC Radio rsquos Today programme: ldquoWe were not fully prepared for this pandemic and, as Irsquove said, Irsquom very happy to accept there is an awful lot to learn.ldquoI think we share some of those failings with many other countries.We are creating the UK Health Security Agencyto protect against future health threats and infectious diseases.This will combine key elements of @phe_uk, the Joint Biosecurity Centre and NHS Test and Trace.Click to find out more #mdash Department of Health and Social CareMarch , Askedthe initial response to the pandemic was poor, she said: ldquoI think it had merits and it had things that we would wish to improve.She said that while asymptomatic transmission had been ldquoconsidered carefully, the proportion of cases ndash now thought to be % ndash was not recognised.ldquoSo obviously the response that we put in place and some of the interventions were not accounting for that high degree of numbers of asymptomatic cases, so I think therersquos learning as wersquove gone through.Asked about face coverings indoors, which were not initially recommended, she said: ldquoWersquove learned more, as Irsquove said, about asymptomatic transmission, and I think we would recommend face coverings earlier.Dr Harries said the issue around testing was that more tests were needed early on.Public Health Englandhas been heavily criticised over a decision to stop community testing and contact tracing last March after it became clear the virus was spreading at a fast pace.Dr Harries said: ldquoWe were using the , tests a day that we had ndash maximum ndash to save lives in the best way we could.There are now ldquohundreds of thousands of tests available, she added. ldquoSo, yes, it would have been good to have had more tests and, yes, we would have used them, but wersquove now processed, I think, nearly  million tests, so clearlylesson haslearned and, I think,lots of opportunities going forward.Dr Harries said the aim of UKHSA is to bring expertise under one roof to fight future threats, including pandemics.Asked what the mission is, she said: ldquoI think the mission is that I wake up every morning and worry about protecting the country, and that clearly is the most valuable mission in public health terms.ldquoWe have learned an awful lot from the pandemic and the value, I think, in the new UK Health Security Agency is in continuing that work, so itrsquos about putting all of the expertise in the country under one roof.Askedthis means moving faster in future, she said: ldquoI think one of There are so many fantastic opportunities here.ldquoIf ever there was a year to enjoy what we have domestically, and to find those spots in Wales that you havenrsquot visited before, this is the year to do it.Mr Drakeford said the Welsh Government will not seek to stop people travelling internationallyrules allow later in the year.ldquoItrsquos not realistic to try to prevent people and we wonrsquot make that attempt.
