title: salmond-urges-sturgeon-work-secure-independence-vote
story: Scotlandrsquos former first minister Alex Salmond has appealed to his successor to ldquoput aside personal dferences and work with him again towards the ldquonoble cause of Scottish independence.The former SNP leader insisted thata ldquosuper majority for independence could be achieved in Mayrsquos Holyrood election with the help of his new Alba Party, it could change the balance of power between Scotland and Westminster.Prime Minister Boris Johnson has consistently refused current First Minister Nicola Sturgeonrsquos calls for a second Scottish independence referendum.But Mr Salmond said thataldquosuper majority of pro-independence MSPs are elected to Holyrood, a range of options would be available to those who want to take Scotland out of the UK.He suggested Scotland could organise its own referendum in those circumstances, with other options including legal action against the UK Government over its refusal to allow such a ballot.Mr Salmond ndash who was unveiled as the leader of the new Alba Party on Friday ndash appealed to Ms Sturgeon to work with him in pursuit of their shared goal.Speaking on the Today programme on BBC Radio , he said: ldquoThe cause of independence is much, much bigger than personalities.ldquoIt is a noble cause, a huge cause for Scotland, and everybody has to put aside personal dferences and work for that national interest.But his plea comes just over a month after he attacked Ms Sturgeon and her administration when giving evidence to the Holyrood committee probing the Scottish Governmentrsquos mishandling of harassment allegations against him.Mr Salmond told MSPs then that Scotlandrsquos ldquoleadership has failed, as he said he had ldquono doubt Ms Sturgeon had broken the ministerial code ndash something an independent inquiry later cleared her of.Speaking about those allegations, Mr Salmond said: ldquoEverybody in politics has to take criticism from time to time.vw,vw,px, px"Alex Salmond has urged Nicola Sturgeon to lsquoput personal dferences asidersquo and work with him again ldquoIrsquom talking about the cause of advancing Scotlandrsquos case for independence.Mr Salmond, who was acquitted last year of  charges of sexual assault, insisted ldquomost fair minded people will respect the verdict of the jury in the case against him.He added: ldquoScotland, I am certain, wants to move on from this and start talking about politics and particularly how we can advance the most noble cause of all ndash and that is the cause of Scottish independence.He insisted a ldquosuper majorityof MSPs in favour of independence would ldquostrengthen immeasurably Scotlandrsquos hand in negotiating with a Tory Prime Minister.He added: ldquoIf Boris Johnson casts this argument about independence as merely the Prime Minister against the First Minister, the Tories against the SNP, then he will likely continue to say no to Scotland.ldquoIf that is against the Parliament and the people, then it changes the power balance considerably, hence the importance of a super majority.Introducing your @AlbaPartyCandidates seeking to secure the Independence #Supermajorityin the Scottish Parliament on May th.Come and join us, be involved, and lets win for #Scotland.Lets #UniteTheYESndash First vote Party, second Country #voteALBAhttps:t.co GgqtxooQcmdash Alba PartyMarch , He recalled that after the  election, when the SNP under his leadership won an overall majority at Holyrood, it ldquobecame much easier to negotiate for an independence referendum to be held.Mr Salmond continued: ldquoA super majority in the Parliament, that is composed of not just one party, the SNP, but other independence parties like Alba, will change that power balance considerably.ldquoBecause no Tory Prime Minister wants to be trying to face down an entire Parliament and an entire people. That would be a very, very dficult position for Boris Johnson..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Salmond urges Sturgeon: Work with me again to secure independence vote

title: vaccine-hesitancy-black-adults-britain-halves---ons
story: The proportion of black or black British adults reporting hesitancy over coronavirus vaccines has halved in roughly a month, official figures show.Overall positive vaccine sentimentamong the British populationhas risen to %in Marchfrom % in December,theOffice for National Statisticssaid.Six per centof , respondentsreported vaccine hesitancy between February  to March  ndash down from% of respondentsduring the previous data collection period.About a fthof black or black British adults reported hesitancy ndash half the % who reported hesitancy previously between January  and February .This was the highest level in all ethnic groups, with % of adultsin theAsianor Asian Britishgroupreporting hesitancyand% of those with mixed ethnicity.vw,vw,px, px"The ONS defined hesitancy as adults who have refused a vaccine, say they would be unlikely to get a vaccine when offered, and those who responded ldquoneither likely nor unlikely, ldquodonrsquot know or ldquoprefer not to say when asked.Levels of hesitancy in younger adultsandparents with a dependent child under five years old also fell.One in eight adults aged - reported vaccine hesitancy in the latest data periodndash down from % between January  and February .Eleven per cent of parents with a dependent child younger than five years old reported hesitancy, compared with % in the previous data period.Our latest analysis of vaccine hesitancy shows % of adults reported hesitancy towards the #COVIDvaccine from  Feb to  Mar .This has fallen from % in the previous period , a trend seen across most population groups https:t.co vUVjBTdpic UeazrVcHmdash Office for National Statistics April , Some % of adults in the most deprived areas of England reported hesitancy, compared with % of adults in the countryrsquos least deprived areas, the ONS said.This was a drop from% and % respectively from the previous data period.Tim Vizard, from the ONS Public Policy Analysis ision, said: ldquoOver the past few months, we have seen attitudes across most of the population becoming more positive towards Covid- vaccination.ldquoHowever, there is still hesitancy among some groups, including young people, black or black British, and those living in the most deprived areas.push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Vaccine hesitancy in black adults in Britain halves  u ONS

title: plot-land-blindwells-goes-sale-housebuilders
story: Marketing has commenced on the .-hectare site, which is called lsquoplot rsquo and is positioned in the northwest corner of the former opencast mine site.Planning permission in principle is already in place for the first phase of the Blindwells development, between Tranent and Cockenzie and Port Seton.Plot  has the capacity to accommodate about  new homes and site owner Hargreaves Land believes it will appeal to housebuilders looking to get a foothold in the new town.Iain Slater, development and estates director at Hargreaves Land, said: ldquoDespite Covid-,  has started on a very positive note for Blindwells.ldquoWe are making excellent progress thanks to our investment in remediation and infrastructure works, but also as a result of the strong underlying demand for good-quality new homes in popular locations.Property consultancy JLL, which is appointed as sole agent for Hargreaves Land, anticipates strong interest and will be seeking offers in late April.The latest announcement follows on the heels of Bellway commencing groundworks on its forthcoming -unit Princersquos Gate development on the Blindwells site.Similarly, in recent weeks Hargreaves Land has also exchanged a conditional sale contract with Persimmon for a .-acre plot where there is capacity for a further  homes, including  designated as affordable.Jason Hogg, director at JLL, said: ldquoHouse prices, sales and demand in East Lothian have surged in the last  months as home buyers seek accommodation that embraces additional space, technology and a high amenity environment ndash Blindwells can capitalise on this and we look forward to discussing the opportunity with the wider market.

title: cockenzie-green-data-centre-plan-branded-giant-shed
story: The latest proposal for the site, which is owned by East Lothian Council, sees it being put forward as one of  prime locations for data centres, which would operate using lsquogreenrsquo energy, by the Scottish Futures Trust.But while the trust says the site is an attractive location to support Scotlandrsquos digital ambitions, Prestonpans community councillor Calum Miller has described it as ldquoanother giant empty shed.The local authority bought the former power station and surrounding land from ScottishPower three years ago and has been marketing it as an important economic site for the county.To date, the only approved plans for the land are an unmanned substation which will bring energy onshore from a windfarm the substation has been described by Prestonpans Community Council and neighbouring Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council as a ldquobig shed.The Host in Scotland initiativefor Scottish Futures Trust is partnered with Scottish Enterprise, whose original plans for a marine energy park on the site seven years ago had to be abandoned after a huge grassroots protest.: Energy park plans scrappedAlongside Crown Estate Scotland, it has published a shortlist of sites which could be green data centres, with Cockenzie number two on the list behind Chapelcross, Annan.The sites are described as offering excellent conditions which ldquocould quickly and easily lend themselves to becoming a large-scale data centrefacility.Data centres are described as buildings where large networks of computer servers are placed by companies to process and store vast amounts of data.East Lothian Council has said that delays in decisions over Cockenzie are being caused because the Scottish Government has still to decide where the site lies in its National Planning Framework plans, which are still being drawn up.In previous NPF strategies, the site has been earmarked as one of national energy importance.Mr Miller questioned why a ferry port bid backed by Prestonpans Community Council was being blocked by concern over national policy while a data centre was being pushed forward.: Cruise terminal talksHe said: ldquoItrsquos odd that NPF is such a huge blocker on a cruise ferry port but welcomes another giant empty shed here with open arms.ldquoThe data centre plan will keep Scottish bureaucrats busy in Edinburgh but it wonrsquot create many employment opportunities in Prestonpans.And he questioned whether promoting the centres in Scotland as a lsquogreenrsquo alternative would attract business.He said: ldquoIrsquove worked in IT all my le but fail to see how Scottish data centres will offer value over what Amazon Google Microsoft are already building on an international basis.ldquoGreen energy is not the market dferentiator the Scottish Government wants it to be.ldquoIT companies purchase cloud resources based on service, price, reliability, security and proximity. A data centre backed by expensive and unreliable wind energy is way down the list.Derek McCrindle,Scottish Enterprise head of place, said that the shortlist of sites would ldquoattract investors looking for a place to host data that can provide the right solutions for the climate and the economy.And the proposal was welcomed by East Lothian MP Kenny MacAskill, who said: ldquoThis is a potential opportunity for the site. Itrsquos something thatrsquos lacking in Scotland and yet badly needed.ldquoIt would bring employment and yet doesnrsquot restrict additional uses. Itrsquos something that council and government must work collaboratively on.

title: uniform-swap-shop-held-prestonpans-help-children-return-school
story: Prestonpans-based Pennypit Community Development Trust launched a lsquounorm swap shoprsquo in mid-March after it was announced that children couldto school following lockdown.The unorm swap shop allows families to donate items that are no longer used for new or second-hand school unorms.Parents are encouraged to visit the stall eventhey do not have anything to donate.Lorna Bellany, Pennypit Development Trust community nutritionist, said: ldquoNot only is there a financial cost to a unorm, but right now school unorms are not in shops, few clothing stores are open and many children have outgrown their current clothes.ldquoWe advocate recycling clothes and many clothing items that children outgrow are still in good condition that others can use, and so the unorm swap-shop is open to the whole community ndash it would be amazingwe could make this a regular occurrence throughout the year.The charity, which works with families across East Lothian, has reported a high number of new referrals due to the financial strain of the Covid- pandemic.Lorna added that the charity group had received positive feedback from parents, who had been thankful to receive clothing that would benefit their children in the new school term.Parents can find skirts, shirts, trousers and school brand jumpers at the Unorm Swap Shop in all sizes.Jumpers for Preston Tower Primary and Nursery, St Gabrielrsquos Primary and Preston Lodge High School will be available for collection.The swap shop will be open tomorrow , .-.pm, and on Friday, .am-.pm at Pennypit Pagoda car park on North Grange Avenue.In line with Covid- restrictions, donated clothes will be quarantined for  hours before being handled and washed.

title: musselburgh-lidl-expand-scottish-craft-beer
story: The discount supermarket chain asked East Lothian Councilrsquos licensing board to allow it to expand the size of its alcohol section by one per cent at its Olivebank store, Musselburgh.The chain said that the move was part of its ongoing Get Fresh expansion programme for stores.And it said that the expanded aisle would be used to sell the craft drinks from Scotland.Lidlrsquos application was approved by the board this week and comes just two months after it successfully applied to expand the alcohol sales in its Prestonpans store.: Lidl accused of drinks monopolyApplying to expand in Musselburgh, Lidl said that the increase would take its normal percentage of store given over to alcohol from . per cent to . per cent, it traditionally goes up around an additional one per cent during the festive season.The chain pointed out that the amount of shelves given over to alcohol in its stores remained half of the lsquoBig Fourrsquo supermarkets, which stocked up to  per cent of their shelves with alcohol.Asking the board to approve the expansion,Lidl said that it would bring the store into line with expansions across Scotland.The chain came under fire from Prestonpans Community Council when it applied to expand in the East Lothian town, with the grouprsquos objection asking what Lidl did for the community.However, at the time, ward councillor Lachlan Bruce highlighted Lidlrsquos work supporting local community initiatives, including food donations to the Pennypit Trust.In applying for the expansion in Musselburgh, Lidl highlighted its work in the local community providing unused food through a Neighbourly scheme which partners with the Hollies Day Centre and Stoneyhill Afterschool Club in the town and Tranent Salvation Army.The board approved the expansion unanimously.

title: dave-berry-column-plotting-course-lockdown-east-lothian
story: Achieving that requires us to lower infection rates further, so that Track and Trace can isolate outbreaks.Few might know this, but the county has survived this awful year reasonably well.This is because we are lumped in with the rest of NHS Lothian, which has generally suffered worse.Last month, infections per week per , were running at  here, while Midlothian was at , West Lothian at  and Edinburgh at .The county is ided into two-dozen infection zones .Last month, threewere over  per , people, with fourbetween  and .The other two-thirds were doing even better.Because cases are in single digits, just one or two cases can make statistics fluctuateDespite Sky News running a scare story of East Lothian soaring to  cases, recent official data contradicts this, with both East Lothianrsquos and Edinburghrsquos rates dropping below  per ,, despite both Midlothian and West Lothian staying above  per ,. These figures represent three per cent of all tests performed.This month, our local figures have improved, but not much. Dunbar West was now over  per ,, while Musselburgh East was at . Two other zonesnow show rates over . All this is retrograde.Fourwere above  cases per , per week.All but one zone are in single figures, some all coming from a single household. But this still compares poorly with Scottish Borders at , or Orkney at zero.No explanation exists why we have seen scant improvement. Commuting into Edinburghremains drastically reduced as many work from home.Spring weather has brought city dwellers to our coast and countryside, but Edinburghrsquos rate of  betters ours of .The impact of schools ing is yet to be felt, but that will be unorm across Scotland.With priority groups to receive vaccine by mid-April and representing  per cent of all those hospitalised, such decline in infection as we have seen here should improve.That said, international travel will remain unlikely, not least because Europe is experiencing a third wave of infections, while relaxation on local travel restrictions should offer a more normal summer of staycationers and opportunity to rediscover our own country.

title: tims-book-road-legends-chapter-seven-secrets-told
story: THE walk up the hill took them through a wood of tall-planted fir trees, but soon the atmosphere changed. Birch trees, hazel, sycamore, beech and Scots pine lined the route, with rowan adding their display of red berries.Izzy reached Creag an Tuirc first. She waited for Finn, hoping hersquod appreciate the view.ldquoWow, he exclaimed as he turned and looked out over Loch Voil.ldquoItrsquos spectacular isnrsquot it  said Izzy, pleased.He walked towards the edge of the rock to get a better vantage point and stopped, just as Izzy was about to nervously grab him. They stood together taking in the spectacle.The loch was blue and shimmering in the now-mist-free sunshine, snuggled in Balquhidder Glen as it stretched westwards.ldquoThis is what it must feel like to be an eagle, Finn said. ldquoAnd itrsquos snack time, he added with a big cheeky grin.They sat cross-legged together, close, but not too close, to the edge, the panorama before them. Izzy opened her rucksack and took out snacks and juice then her stove, kettle and bottled water.ldquoCoffee time too, she said.Sunshine bathed them and Finn now noticed the sweet fragrance of the wood.Izzy soaked in the beauty of the place and magic of the moment. As Finn ate his snacks, she cast her gaze towards an old Scots pine which stood guard by them.ldquoSo what about this placersquos secrets, then  Finn asked.Izzy collected small sticks and twigs which lay where she sat and made a small pyramid shape with them.ldquoWhatrsquos that ldquoA pretend fire, she said. ldquoIrsquom going to tell a story that has been told for hundreds of years as people sat by their hearth, so this is our hearth.ldquoBut itrsquos a warm day, we donrsquot need one.ldquoThe hearth wasnrsquot just for warmth, it was the soul of the house, the gathering place, replied Izzy. She lit her stove and made coffee as Finn added a few more twigs to their hearth. Coffee made, she was ready to tell the story.Izzy pointed eastwards: ldquoOver there, on a joyful August day, people had gathered for the fair of St Angus when a large force of Buchanan clansmen were seen approaching. They were heavily armed and clearly intent on a fight. But nobody understood why.ldquoThey were from the clan who had bullied the young boy, said Finn.ldquoYes, but remember he hadnrsquot told anyone. Now, in a panic, he explained to his horried kinsfolk the humiliating incident with the fish and what hersquod said.ldquoThere was no time to waste runners with the fiery cross were sent immediately through the glen to summon MacLaren men to battle.ldquoBut bloody slaughter was already under way the glen resounded with screams of terror, the clash of swords and the cry of men cut and dying as the Buchanan clansmen attacked.ldquoOutnumbered and unprepared, the MacLarens retreated to the foot of this rock, cornered like a boar in a hunt.Izzy paused in her telling to drink coffee.Finn stood up and peered at the land far below the rock: ldquoJust down there Izzy nodded.ldquoWhat happened to the MacLarens, were they all killed Izzy indicated to Finn to come back and sit with her. He took one final look over the edge then sat with his aunt, keen to hear what happened next.ldquoA boar is at its most dangerous when cornered, thatrsquos when it will attack ferociously, she said. ldquoWith their backs against this rock, the MacLarens had nowhere to run they had no choice but to fight for their lives.Izzy imitated the sound of swords clashing and waved her right arm asshe had a sword. Finn fought her in the air with his imaginary sword. His aunt stopped the role play with a serious look on her face.ldquoA heart-rending cry was heard, she said. ldquoA brave but young MacLaren warrior had been cut down at his fatherrsquos side. The father fell to his knees and cradled his dead son. His grief turned into a rage for revenge.ldquoHe screamed lsquoCreag an Tuirc!rsquo as he charged towards his sonrsquos killer. It electried his fellow clansmen, they fought like crazy men.They both ed to their imaginary sword fight for a few moments, re-enacting the scene.ldquoWho won  asked Finn.ldquoWell, the rage of the MacLarens began to turn the tide, then more of their warriors arrived. The Buchanan men began to flee. They were chased and cut down.ldquoYes! said Finn, who stood up and found a stick which he used to fight imaginary opponents.ldquoDid all the bullies get killed  he asked.Izzy stood up and looked south towards the River Balvaig which curled from the loch. Finn joined her.ldquoAye, no mercy was given, none were spared. The last two made a desperate attempt to escape by crossing the river over there. They were chased and both met their end, the last one at a place called Sron Lainie which we passed earlier.Izzy sat back down by the hearth and cradled her mug of coffee.ldquoEver since that battle, this rock has been the rallying point for the MacLaren clan, and Creag an Tuirc their war cry.Finn stood like a victorious warrior, stick in hand, looking out at the scene of the battle. It was so calm and beautul, not a hint of the bloody history hersquod just been told.He asked a question: ldquoWhat about the lad, you know, whorsquod had the fish, what happened to him ldquoHe wasnrsquot a fighter, explained Izzy, ldquoso he wasnrsquot in the battle. People blamed him because he hadnrsquot told of the incident earlier. Who knows what he must have felt inside at all the death people said hersquod caused.Finn raised his voice with passion: ldquoBut he didnrsquot cause it, the stupid bullies did! He didnrsquot tell about what happened because he wanted to hide his humiliation. He was hurt and being bullied. How was he to know this would happen Izzy nodded: ldquoI think yoursquore right Finn ndash the bullies just used it as an excuse. But sometimes people feel guilt even when they arenrsquot really to blame.Finn nodded as he scanned the landscape, then swiped his stick against the trunk of a tree so hard the stick broke in two.ldquoIs it a true story aunty Izzy got up and stood by him: ldquoThere is disagreement about when it happened, but it is a traditional tale long told and seems based on real events, but who can say for sure.Finn looked at his aunt: ldquoI wish I could speak to him and explain it wasnrsquot his fault.ldquoMe too, said Izzy. She laid her hand gently on his arm. ldquoMaybe someone did. Maybe he realised himself.Finn looked at the ground and gave a slight nod. ldquoAt least the bullies lost, he said.ldquoEveryone did, said Izzy, ldquothere were no winners,you think about it. Thatrsquos the stupidity of it all.Finn thought for a moment, then went to the rucksack to take a bottle of water.He drank with big gulps aswashing something down. He threw the empty plastic bottle into the undergrowth.ldquoYou said there was a mystery about Rob Royrsquos grave, can you tell me that too ldquoSure, replied Izzy, ldquoafter yoursquove put that bottle in our bag for rubbish, you know better than that Finn.Finn settled by the hearth and Izzy looked at her nephew, wondering where to start.ldquoThe thing is, she said, ldquoI believe Rob Royrsquos grave probably isnrsquot really the grave of Rob Roy!Finn laughed: ldquoWhat  How can you say that His aunt told how the story in the glen was that Rob had been wounded in a sword fight with a man called John MacLaren, with whom he had had a dispute over land. It was Robrsquos last fight and the wound he received eventually caused his death.She explained that it was said his body was then carried along a coffin trail which went over the hills to the west of the glen at a place called Bealach nan Corp, which means pass of the corpses.The trail led to the shore of Loch Lomond, the earlier home of Rob Roy, then to an island called Inchcailloch where many of his ancestors are buried.ldquoIt was common for dead people to be carried many miles to their ancestral burial ground, Izzy explained, ldquobecause resting with your ancestors was important in clan culture. Thatrsquos why there are so many coffin trails all over the Highlands.ldquoYou mean paths to carry dead people to graveyards ldquoYep.ldquoBut what about the gravestone at his grave here  asked Finn.ldquoThat stone is very old and lay in the kirk long before Rob was even born, it commemorates a warrior lost to memory, most likely a MacLaren. The MacLaren clan was the first to hold sway here.ldquoThe gravestones claimed to be of Rob and his family lie in the foundations of the oldest church, which was associated with the MacLarens even before the MacGregors arrived in this glen. Using old gravestones did happen, but I think Rob will have wanted to rest with his ancestors.Finn was confused: ldquoSoitrsquos not really his grave, why would anyone say it is Izzy pointed towards the south.ldquoAlthough Rob was well known in his letime, after his death he was turned into a famous legend by the historical novels of a man called Walter Scott. Wealthy tourists came here in droves in the th century, on horse and cart, then later by train. They wanted to see the places described in the book just as people do now with films.ldquoLike the phone box from Local Hero, proclaimed Finn.ldquoExactly. It became a romantic pilgrimage and pilgrims need a shrine to visit. So I think someone began the story that those old gravestones marked Rob and his familyrsquos graves, then later the story caught on and had become so popular that in  even Queen Victoria visited the grave, giving the story royal approval. Interestingly, when she visited there were two stones, not three.ldquoWho started this story then  asked Finn, who wasnrsquot sure whether to be disappointed or amused at the audacity of it all.ldquoI suspect we will never know, his aunt replied. ldquoOne way to prove it either way would bethere was an excavation, anda skeleton of a short man with long arms was found, then Irsquod admit I was wrong.ldquoSo you admit you might be wrong then ldquoItrsquos always important to consider you may be wrong Finn, but when something is believed for long enough it can become a truth based on tradition and faith. Some will choose to believe it, while others wonrsquot one personrsquos truth can be anotherrsquos heresy.Finn tried to follow his auntrsquos meaning but hersquod got lost after the skeleton. He knew she was clever shersquod often have deep discussions with his stepdad and mum that he wouldnrsquot understand. But this was dferent, she was talking to him and he wanted to understand.ldquoWhatrsquos heresy  he asked.ldquoItrsquos when you believe something thatrsquos not believed by others, who think they alone have all the truth, she explained.Finn raised his eyebrows: ldquoLike a teacher.Izzy laughed: ldquoLike a bad teacher, yes.ldquoLetrsquos get going, she said, dismantling the hearth and placing the twigs randomly back on the ground.ldquoHave you noticed something missing in all these stories  she asked. Finn shook his head.ldquoWomen! Izzy replied. ldquoItrsquos time for a tale about an intrepid woman, methinks Irsquoll tell you her story as we head back down the hill.ldquoIt may even have a connection to the name Creag an Tuirc, which meanshellip she looked at Finn for the answerhellipldquoRock of the boar, he said proudly.Here are the links to chapters one, two, three, four, five and six.

title: face-mask-rules-scotland-mandatory-coverings-eased
story: Since June, wearing a covering has been mandatory on all public transport in Scotland.A month later, it became law in shops.But as Scotland looks towards an exit from lockdown ndash with First Minister Nicola Sturgeon outlining a route map to Level  earlier this month ndash it raises the question: how much longer will we have to wear masks Here, we outline when other countries have eased their mandatory mask policies, and what has been said so far in Scotland.In Australia, the state of Victoria eased restrictions on Friday meaning masks will no longer be mandatory in retail settings.They will, however, need to be worn on public transport, hospitals, care homes and taxis.They also will have to carry masks with them, and are being urged to wear them when physical distancing is not possible.It comes after  days without any local cases of the virus there.Elsewhere, in New South Wales, masks will no longer be mandatory ndash including on public transport.The state has recorded just two cases of community transmission in the past two months mdash both linked to the states hotel quarantine programme.Chief medical officer Kerry Chant said the restrictions were beingscrappedon the basis that there was nocommunity transmission of Covid.Given that Scotland has also introduced a mandatory hotel quarantine scheme, it could be hoped thatlocal community transmission can be reduced to similarly low levels, then we could eventually follow suit in mask policy.In America, despite President Joe Biden making it clear restrictions are still necessary, the state of Texas has ended its mask requirement.Mississippi has also followed suit. However, health experts are warning the pandemic is far from over there, with cases likely to pick upcurbs were lted too soon.Passengers will be asked to wear face masks on Ryanair flights potentially until , the airlinersquos boss has said, as he announced ato a more normal summer schedule.The budget airline plans to run around , flights every day during the summer this year, Michael OrsquoLeary said.ldquoI would imagine at this point in time, wersquore planning to continue to require mandatory face mask wearing on board our aircraft through the remainder of this summer schedule and next winterrsquos schedule, Mr OrsquoLeary said.According to the Scottish Governmentrsquos website, ldquoin all levels and settings, we should follow ldquoadvice and requirements such as on the use of face coverings.Speaking on March  when she outlined Scotlandrsquos route map out of the pandemic, the First Minister said that it is ldquohoped that we could reach ldquoat least Level  by the end of June.Currently, guidance under Level  includes the mandatory wearing of face coverings on public transport and shops ndash unless you are exempt.However, Ms Sturgeon said that ldquowe hope we will be able to get beyond even that, with a ldquoview to restoring as much normality as possible.Wersquove shared our timeline for a safe and gradual easing of restrictions in Scotland.All dates are dependent on scientic evidence that it is safe to ease further.Watch our video to find out more ##Read the timeline ## https:t.co XabMrdBXjt pic QoVbuyaXVShe told MSPs: ldquoIt is our fervent hope - and also our tentatively increasing expectation - that vaccination, continued and effective use of the test and protect system, and probably a continued compliance with precautions like good hand hygiene, will allow us to keep Covid under much greater control.ldquoAnd that this will allow us to enjoy many of the things that we took for granted before the pandemic ndash for example, normal family gatherings where we can hug our loved ones, sporting events, gigs and nightclubs.She said that she is ldquooptimistic this date will be over the summer, adding ldquohopefully something closer to actual normality, with the ability to hug those we love, will become possible.From this, we can establish that the wearing of face coverings is likely to be in place for some time yet.The First Minister has pointed towards ldquoactual normality by some point in the summer, suggesting thatthe science backs things up, there could be a potential relaxation of the rules around masks.However,we look towards the decisions being made in Australia, the levels of cases may need to get to extremely low levels for this to take place.

title: plea-owners-dogs-disturbing-birds-levenhall-links-nature-reserve
story: Posters have been put up at Levenhall Links in support of the Responsible Dog Ownership Campaign, launched by the Scottish Government in partnership with the Scottish SPCA.The initiative seeks to remind dog owners that they have a legal responsibility to keep their dog under proper control in order to prevent and reduce the risk of incidents.The posterswere put up at the nature attraction ndash which once hosted RSPB Scotlandrsquos Big Nature Festival ndash by East Lothian Councilrsquos countryside rangers, who are also targeting other sites in the county.A council spokeswoman said that, as the weather improved, the days ened and people exercised outdoors, it was appropriate to remind dog walkers to keep dogs under control.She said: ldquoAt this time of year in countryside sites there may be young birds or nests that can be disturbed by dogs running off lead.ldquoThe posters are to remind dog owners to keep their pets close to hand and not to encourage behaviour that may cause problems to wildle or indeed other visitors.ldquoThis issue of countryside disturbance is not unique to Levenhall Links or East Lothian but is recognised throughout the UK as more people are accessing the countryside than ever before and are unaware of how their actions can have an adverse impact on wildle.ldquoIt has been estimated around . million pets had been bought in the UK during lockdown. Potentially, thatrsquos a lot of new dogs out in the countryside and a lot of new owners who are not necessarily aware of appropriate behaviour for their pet.Levenhall Links is a bird reserve within a Site of Special Scientic Interest which, at the access point, has a large wooden sign advising people to stay on the path and to use the hides to observe birds.A peregrine falcon hunting over the bird reserve. Image: Ian AndrewsThe council spokesperson said: ldquoUnfortunately, both people and dogs are walking off the paths and disturbing ious species of birds. One is the issue of ground nesting birds. We are entering the breeding season and last year was a very poor year for ground nesting birds, which is thought to be largely due to disturbance.ldquoSkylarks, meadow pipit and grey partridge are the key species in Musselburgh that suffer from disturbance.ldquoThe key message is lsquoareas of uncut coastal grassland may have nesting birds presentrsquo. Try to avoid these areas between April  and July , and stick to areas of cut grasslandyou wish to exercise your dog off-lead.The bird reserve at the lagoons is a wetland bird reserve, with wading birds roosting and feeding.ldquoOut-of-control dogs out of their ownerrsquos sight are having a negative impact, said the council spokesperson.One local birdwatcher recently tweeted about disturbance, which was retweeted by naturalist and television presenter Chris Packham and generated a lot of discussion.The council spokesperson said: ldquoIt seems  was a bad year for wildle throughout the whole of the UK due to more people out and about. The message is to think about where to walk your dog. Try to avoid estuaries where birds are feeding and remember that nature reserves and coastal grassland are sensitive areas.Jason Rose, chairman of community group Friends of Musselburgh Links, said: ldquoThis has been an issue on and off over the years but does seem to have got worse in recent weeks. Putting up fresh signs to make things clearer should help.ldquoItrsquos really importantyou bring dogs to the lagoons, whether you are the owner or a commercial walker, you stay away from the wader scrapes. There is fencing all the way round this area for a reason.ldquoThere is plenty of space where on the links to exercise dogs. Many owners are responsible, and we thank them.ldquoHowever, I also know that, on occasion, when a dog walker has been approached about disruptive behaviour, they have shown disinterest in the issue. These incidents clearly arenrsquot accidents and thatrsquos heartbreaking.ldquoThe lagoons are a Site of Special Scientic Interest and there were already prominent signs making this clear, asking people to stick to the paths and keep quiet. Dogs off the lead in this area will cause ground-nesting birds to scatter, leaving eggs and chicks vulnerable. This could be devastating for future populations of wildle which bring so much joy.

title: longniddry-couple-preparing-celebrate-platinum-wedding-anniversary
story: Bob, now , and Mary, , first met when Mary was a nurse in a Hawick hospital, and Bob ndash on leave from the RAF at the time and whose family were tenant farmers just outside the town ndash was visiting his sick mother there.But it wasnrsquot until , when they met again at a dance in Maryrsquos home town of Coldstream and Bob recognised her, that they began courting.They were married in Coldstream on a snowy Saturday on March , .David said: ldquoBecause of the snow, it was touch and go whether my father would make it from Hawick to Coldstream for the wedding, because the farm was  miles in the hills and they woke up to a blanket of snow, and they had to clear the roads from the farm to get out!First settling in Gordon for  years, they then moved to Penicuik, where Bob was an insurance superintendent with Prudential. There they had three children: David, Jean and Hazel.When the children were at high school, Mary retrained as a primary school teacher, taking a post in Penicuik.Bob and Mary moved to Longniddry in , and Mary then taught at Prestonpans Primary School until both she and Bob retired in .During the  years they have lived in Longniddry, they have been very active in the community, with Bob a member of Tranent Rotary Club for many years, a past president of the club and now an honorary member.As a fiddle player, he was also part of Haddington Fiddlers and then East Lothian Fiddlers.Mary has been involved with Tranent Inner Wheel during her time in Longniddry, and is also a past president of the club, still attending meetings via Zoom.The couple, who have seven grandchildren,  great-grandchildren and two great-great-grandchildren, are regular church-goers who have been involved in many church initiatives. They were also both members of Longniddry Golf Club for many years.It is this active lestyle that David credits for his parents being so happy and healthy.He said: ldquoTheyrsquove been blessed with good health and are determined to be independent.ldquoAnd their involvement with people is whatrsquos keeping them going.

title: liberal-democrats-announce-candidate-midlothian-north-musselburgh-seat
story: Liberal Democrat Charles Dundas, a former City of Edinburgh councillor, has pledged to prioritise recovering from the Covid- pandemic.He said: ldquoCovid- has drastically affected our health service, our economy, and the world of education ndash and getting all of them back on track should be at the heart of what the next Scottish Government focuses on.ldquoThe Scottish Liberal Democrats have just one political priority at this time ndash recovering from the pandemic crisis.Mr Dundas, a history graduate from the University of Glasgow, has worked as an accountant for the National Australia Bank and researcher in the Scottish Parliament.He was also a consultant for a commercial public affairs firm.He is currently chief executive of the Borders Forest Trust and is a former trustee of the Royal Lyceum Theatre.In his spare time, Mr Dundas performs locally and abroad with an improv troupe and has appeared at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe a number of times.: Conservatives, Labour and SNP announce Midlothian North and Musselburgh candidatesBetween  and  he was elected to City of Edinburgh Council, where he chaired the Administration group and served on the planning committee as well as the transport, environment and infrastructure committee, and the education committee. He was also a member of the Lothian and Borders Police Board.Mr Dundas said: ldquoMidlothian North and Musselburgh deserves an MSP who prioritises those issues which are most important to our daily lives and not one who just wants to play with the endless political footballs of Brexit or independence. I want to see the Scottish Liberal Democrats elected and able to boost Scotlandrsquos mental health services, to create jobs and to help pupils catch up.ldquoAs a committed environmentalist, I am also determined that our recovery from the pandemic should go hand in hand with the urgent recovery that Scotlandrsquos nature needs to help us tackle the climate emergency.ldquoWe have a big job ahead of uswe want to build a Scotland that we can be proud to pass to on to the generations to come but our most important priority should be putting recovery first.Also contesting the seat at the election is sitting MSP Colin Beattie , Midlothian councillor Stevie Curranand City of Edinburgh councillor Iain Whyte .The nomination period closes on Wednesday.

title: fate-dunbar-assembly-rooms-set-decided-week
story: Discussions surrounding the future of Dunbarrsquos B-listed Assembly Rooms have been ongoing for more than  years.On Tuesday, members of East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee will consider plans for the Church Street building, which include the creation of four flats. Previous proposals, for the building to be turned into eight flats, were rejected by the councilrsquos planning department.Now, planners are recommending the latest scheme be approved. Ward councillor Norman Hampshire, who is the convener of the planning committee, called in the proposals from Alexander Williamson. He wanted his colleagues on the planning committee to consider the parking situation on Church Street as well as the proposed alterations to the building, which dates back to .Three objections and two representations ndash which offered support and raised concerns ndash had been submitted.Among the concerns was the parking situation, something which was also highlighted by Dunbar Community Council in its own submissions.According to the planning officerrsquos report, they welcomed ldquoa sympathetic conversion to bring the building back into use but were concerned over ldquothe non-provision of resident parking.There is no off-street parking proposed for the site, with the councilrsquos roads service team stating ldquothey cannot support this application. The report continues: ldquoHowever, roads services acknowledge that this is an existing building that is close to Dunbar town centre which is well served by public transport.Mr Williamson and those representing him had called on the council to approve the proposals, which they described as ldquothe only course of action left.Currently, the building has three occupied flats in the basement, with the remainder of the building having been vacant for some  years.The last known use was as a furniture shop in , with the building gradually declining since then and listed on Scotlandrsquos Buildings at Risk register.

title: virtual-lands-end-john-ogroats-walk-help-preston-lodge-high-school-pipe-band
story: Pipe Major Lee Moore is among a group of  looking to raise thousands of pounds to buy unorms for members of Preston Lodge High School Pipe Band.The fundraisers are walking  miles ndash the distance from Landrsquos End to John OrsquoGroats ndash with each unorm costing between pound and pound.Mr Moore , who has been the pipe major for about  years, told the Courier: ldquoDuring lockdown, I, like many others, have been doing a lot of walking and getting out, especially with teaching being online for so long.ldquoYou need a break and some fresh air every wee while to get rid of screen fatigue.ldquoWe have been stepping it up, and myself and band secretary Catriona Black had a wee competition to see who could do the most steps each day.ldquoI spotted on Facebook the idea of the lsquoend to end challengersquo from Landrsquos End to John OrsquoGroats virtually.ldquoI signed up and told Catriona and she signed up too.ldquoWe decided we would do it as a kind of sponsored walk to get some cash in for the unorms we were looking for.ldquoWe told the parents about it and eight of them have signed up.The challenge got under way at the beginning of the month, with each of the  walkers already beyond the -mile mark.Mr Moore highlighted that the walking had opened his eyes to what was on offer in Musselburgh, where he lives.He had enjoyed walking ldquosporadically but was now enjoying the great outdoors.The -year-old said: ldquoIt has been great. You discover lots of stuff in your own locality that you never knew before and Irsquove seen all seasons.ldquoI regularly walk up along the side of the Esk ndash you just see it all.Walkers are aiming to reach the virtual finish line by the end of August, with hopes of the band marching through Prestonpans, Cockenzie and Port Seton, and Longniddry later in the year.The fundraisers are looking to raise pound, for the band, with more than pound, already donated by generous members of the public.The band, which has about  members, is made up of pipers and drummers from throughout the Preston Lodge school cluster.Mr Moore was looking forward to members being able to get back together, with the bandrsquos last performance having been on St Patrickrsquos Day in Portobello last year.He said: ldquoIt has been very hard. It has been tough and it is a big part of our lives, especially the competing pipe band scene.ldquoThe whole of last season was cancelled and at the moment everything up until June has been cancelled.ldquoWe are keeping our fingers crossed that the World Championships go ahead in August to some degree but it is tough for the kids.ldquoThey have not had that side of it as well to look forward to but they have stuck in.ldquoTheir resilience is amazing.To support the pipe band, go to www.justgiving crowdfunding plhspipeband

title: prestonpans-post-office-retain-services-following-pressure-community-council
story: Located in the townrsquos Scotmid store on High Street, the Post Office is set to change to a local model and, as a result, some services, including banking, were set to be changed or removed.Customers requiring passports checked, travel insurance or financial services would have had to travel to Tranent or Musselburghthe changes had gone ahead.But after efforts by the townrsquos community council to keep these services in the town, Scotmid confirmed that all services in the Post Office would be retained.However, the secure counter is due to be removed, meaning those wishing to bank a large amount of money must hold it in the queue until it is their turn to be served.Speaking to Brian Weddell, chairman of Prestonpans Community Council, a spokesperson for Scotmid said: ldquoAfter many discussions, I am pleased to confirm we will now retain all services that were available in the mains office when we convert to the local model.ldquoI would like to thank you for your and the community councilrsquos feedback and time to date.ldquoWe are delighted to retain these services for the local community.Members of Prestonpans Community Council shared their joy at the news at its virtual meeting earlier this month, saying it was ldquogood to see their concerns had been listened to.

title: zans-wildlife-diary-mad-march-hares
story: I had been wanting to photograph brown hares for more than a year and only last March did I finally take great pleasure in not only photographing the hares but capturing them boxing.Before then, I had spent hundreds of hours visiting dferent fields and meadows within and outside East Lothian in search of brown hares.After each defeat, the desire to photograph these creatures was getting stronger and stronger.I appreciate this could be discouraging for some, but I do not give up easily, even in my private le! I suppose perseverance is the province of every wildle photographer.Finally, one sunny afternoon, Chris and I decided to go for a drive around the local fields.The road was quite narrow, and we had to pull over to let another car go past.As soon as we stopped, I opened the window and saw them ndash a good dozen hares chasing across the field.Usually, you see only one or a couple at most, so this sighting was exceptional.We parked up in haste and rushed towards the binkying hares. They were moving fast and chaotically, making it dficult to keep them in sight.One minute they were boxing and a second later they were all leaping high up. I could even see hair and saliva flying in the air ndash the field looked like it turned into a real boxing ring!As soon as the group flashed near us, I grabbed for my faithful camera and took several shots.There can be some confusion about whether or not the lsquoboxingrsquo hares are fighting, and whether this is an act between two malesor a male and female .This frantic behaviour usually occurs when a surge of testosterone pushes a buck to chase after his chosen doe across the fields in an attempt to mate.A doe can be chased by multiple bucks throughout the spring, which can understandably become a bit tiresome.This is when a female would turn around and fight a male off by initiating the boxing match. It is not unusual to see fur flying.It is believed that brown hares have lived in the UK since Roman times but are now considered naturalised.Their distinctive long, black-tipped ears and fast running make them easily distinguishable from rabbits.They are also much bigger and do not dig burrows.Hares live above ground in the open and dig lsquoformsrsquo: shallow depressions in the ground or grass.They can easily sink in the forms and blend in with the environment but, when disturbed, they take off and bound across the fields, often in a zigzag pattern.Brown hares can reach a speed of  miles per hour, which makes them Britainrsquos fastest land animal.Unlike many other British mammals, hares do not hibernate or store fat, so they need a constant food supply. They feed on a iety of grasses, herbs, twigs and bark to stay healthy.March and April are the best months to watch brown hares boxing, so I would like to encourage everyone to visit the local fields.Keep your eyes peeled for the hares and stay safe!www.facebook zanslens www.instagram zans_lens www zans_lens

title: incredibly-disappointing-cancel-haddington-show-say-organisers
story: The show, one of East Lothianrsquos most popular annual events, had been due to take place on June .However, for the second consecutive year, the committee of the United East Lothian Agricultural Societyhas made the dficult choice to not go ahead with the event.Alan Thomson, UELAS chairman, was disappointed to see the show again shelved due to coronavirus restrictions.However, he stressed that the safety of everyone involved was critical and it was not a decision taken lightly.In a statement, he said: ldquoCurrent Scottish Government guidelines suggest it would be almost impossible to run the event, which would usually attract a sea of competitors, trade stands, and visitors, from many dferent areas of Scotland and the north of England.ldquoThe safety of all our stakeholders is of paramount importance and, as such, we felt it was too great a risk to allow the show to take place this year.ldquoThe committee have already invested much time into the advance planning and organising of the event however, we all decided it would be in the best interests of the society to cancel now, rather than continue and risk costing the society money the longevity of UELAS is of utmost importance to us all.And he added: ldquoBeing forced to cancel our show for the second consecutive year is incredibly disappointing and we know how many people were looking forward to their annual visit to East Fortune.ldquoAlong with many others, we devote a great deal of time and have a huge emotional attachment to the show, so cancelling was certainly not a decision taken lightly.ldquoPlease take care of yourselves and your loved ones. We hope to have your continued support in , and that we see you at our show next year.East Lothian Provost John McMillan, who represents the Haddington and Lammermuir council ward, was keen to see the showin impressive fashion in .The local authorityrsquos spokesman for tourism and economic development said: ldquoSadly, event organisers are having to take some tough decisions this year again while we move through the progressive stages of easing lockdown, but public safety is always top priority.ldquoI very much hope to see the enormously popular Haddington Showeven stronger next year.ldquoIn the meantime, I am hopeful that East Lothian can host some events later in , albeit perhaps in dferent ways, and the council is continuing to work with all business sectors including retail, hospitality and tourism to do what we can to help our economy recover post-pandemic.

title: knox-academy-pupils-get-chance-questions-east-lothian-candidates-scottish-parliament-election
story: A new MSP for the county will be elected at the Scottish Parliament elections on May  as current MSP Iain Grayis retiring.Now, Knox Academy pupils, parents carers, family members and staff are being invited to a series of live webinars.Sue Cook, headteacher at the Haddington secondary school, described it as ldquoan exciting occasion.Pupils will work alongside staff to run a series of ldquoinformative, fun and participatory sessions in the run-up to the election.The headteacher said: ldquoThe programme will include live lsquoHow torsquo guides on registering to vote and voting on election day, delivered by pupils and staff.ldquoThere will also be a live Virtual Knox Academy Question Time Debate Night with an opportunity for you, as our audience, to ask questions at live QA sessions with the candidates for the East Lothian constituency seat.ldquoPaul McLennan , Craig Hoy , Martin Whitfieldand Euan Davidsonhave already been in touch to express their excitement at the prospect and canrsquot wait to answer your questions.ldquoThere will also be an opportunity to flex your political knowledge, with prizes on offer for predicting the outcomes of ious elements of the election result.ldquoThe full programme, with dates and times for all the webinars, is to follow.

title: north-berwick-twins-81-team-new-novel
story: Helen and Morna Mulgray, of Melbourne Road, North Berwick, are -year-old twin sisters who teamed up to write their latest crime novel.The pair are both former English teachers at schools in Midlothian: Helen worked at Greenhill High School in Gorebridge ndash it has since been demolished ndash and Morna at Lasswade High School in Bonnyrigg.Former keen snowboarders and archers, Morna and Helen are also former members of the Edinburgh Writers Group.Nowadays they are members of the North Berwick Theatre Group and look forward to being able to resume its trips when restrictions allow.The pair moved from Portobello to North Berwick six years ago and live together in the same house, something that makes writing their books easier but also more enjoyable.They started writing during the school holidays while working as teachers and have now written and released their latest novel Suspicious Activities in Plain View after six years of working on it.It is the seventh novel in their DJ Smith and Gorgonzola series.The image of the Bass Rock on the front cover was one taken themselves, something also replicated in most of their books.They said: ldquoWe write tasteful crime novels but gory violence isnrsquot our kind of writing. There are several murders but the violence is always tastefully done, no nightmares!ldquoSuspense mixed with light humour, thatrsquos what we like ndash and thatrsquos what yoursquoll find in our series.The pair said they spent about two hours a day working on their books, as it was best to spend as much time working on it, asthey did not they might lose track of their workload and ideas.The novelrsquos heroine, DJ Smith, is an investigator for HM Revenue and Customs with her trained snfer cat Gorgonzola, a motheaten Persian with a mind of her own.The sister duo, who were born  minutes apart, added: ldquoPeople are always asking us how two people go about writing a book together.ldquoWell, itrsquos easy when yoursquore a twin ndash same way of thinking, same ideas, same style.ldquoIt isnrsquot a case of taking turns to write a sentence, a paragraph or a chapter.ldquoOne of us types on the laptop and then both of us make suggestions, of a word, phrase or sentence ndash all mulled over till mutually agreed!ldquoTo quote Robert Louis Stevenson: lsquoSome places speak of a story.rsquo Background can be as interesting as plot.ldquoIn our first novel, No Suspicious Circumstances, trips to Cramond Island, Tantallon Castle, Longniddry Bents, the top of Arthurrsquos Seat, and the islands of Inchcolm and May were enjoyable as well as useful.ldquoWersquove just finished the seventh novel in the series. Readers will enjoy the familiar settings.The first two books were published by Allison and Busby and the next two by Robert Hale.The other three books have been published by the twins themselves.They do not have the rights to their first two books but this is something they are working on.The books written by the Mulgray twins are all available on Amazon, Blackwellrsquos, Book Depository and bookshop.orgThey added a word of encouragement to other budding writers.They said: ldquoWe want to encourage writers that evenyou donrsquot have a publisher, you can still do somethingyou work hard and have enough perseverance.ldquoJoin a writersrsquo groupthere is one available in your area, the competitions are great.

title: east-lothian-food-drink-appoints-new-directors-help-sector-recover
story: The group ndash a lsquobusiness improvement districtrsquondash has welcomed Ian Smith, head of corporate relations at Diageo Scotland, which owns Glenkinchie Distillery at Pencaitland and David Albers, commercial director at Purely Scottish Water, based at Oldhamstocks, to its board, which comprises five members of representative companies, as well as members of East Lothian Council.Ian, who lives in North Berwick, said: ldquoThere has never been a more important time for collaboration amongst businesses than now, as we all face the challenge of rebuilding in the wake of the Covid- pandemic, and Irsquom pleased to be able to do my bit by joining the board of this brilliant organisation.David said: ldquoAs Scotlandrsquos first and only sector-based business improvement district, East Lothian Food and Drink is clearly an ambitious organisation and Irsquom looking forward to helping shape it as we reset our priorities and help our sector recover in  and beyond.The BID, a collaboration of local food and drink businesses formed in , is preparing to launch a renewal ballot to seek a second five-year term.Ian added: ldquoThe BID renewal gives us a pivotal opportunity to work together and to make East Lothian synonymous with quality food and drink produce and visitor experiences.Chris Luca, chair of East Lothian Food and Drink, said: ldquoWe are delighted to welcome Ian and David to our board, as we plan to ask our members to vote yes to a second term for the BID. This strengthened board will allow East Lothian Food and Drink to play an important role in supporting the recovery of our industry from the crisis of the last year.

title: mekala-osborne-hopes-walk-unaided-end-year
story: Mekala, , was travelling through South East Asia with a friend in the autumn of  when she became seriously ill.The former Preston Lodge High School pupil then spent the next  months recovering from necrotising pneumonia and was at one point given just a five per cent chance of survival. Her family were told to ldquoexpect the worst.At hospitals in Vietnam, Singapore and Edinburgh, she underwent intense treatment for the le-threatening illness, which included invasive surgery on one lung that had fully collapsed.Her mum Yvonne McAulay, who works as a bus driver for Harlawhill Day Care Centre in Prestonpans, flew out to be by her daughterrsquos side while she was receiving treatment in Asia.In November , Mekala was flown home to Manchester and transported by ambulance to the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh.In March last year, she was transported to the Astley Ainslie Hospital, also in Edinburgh, for further treatment.During her stay at the Astley Ainslie, Mekala underwent gruelling rehabilitation, including learning to walk as she spent nearly  days lying down after becoming ill.She was also previously told she might never walk again. From the pneumonia she developed muscular neuropathy during the two weeks she was in a coma. Her muscles went to sleep and deteriorated as her body was using all of its energy for her vital organs.In July last year, a video was shared of Mekala taking her first steps. She used a frame, with two members of staff helping move her legs while another followed behind with a wheelchair.After her stay in rehab, Mekala was finally able toto the family home, where brother Danny also lives, on Dury Way on December , welcomed by a crowd of  friends and neighbours.: Mekala Osborne s homeAnd now, Mekala has shared a video on social media of her walking from the front door of the house to a car parked on the road opposite with her only assistance being holding her mumrsquos hand." alt"East Lothian Courier: Mekala Osborne taking steps with the aid of her mum. Image Facebook " class"editor-image"After she successfully reaches the car, mum Yvonne claps and also has a little dance.Mekala then opens the car door herself and appears to begin to sit inside." alt"East Lothian Courier: Mekala Osborne taking steps with the aid of her mum. Image Facebook " class"editor-image"She said: ldquo goal ndash say goodbye to the crutches and to be able to do the slosh. PS my mumrsquos clap at the end is the cutest thing ever.

title: elphinstone-couple-celebrate-diamond-wedding-anniversary
story: Peter and Helen Fairgrieve celebrated their diamond anniversary last Thursday.Peter, who was brought up in the village, was born on May , , and went to Elphinstone School.Helen was born nine days later, on May , , growing up in Tranent and becoming a pupil at Tranent Primary School. The pair both attended Tranent Public School.Helen worked most of her le as a cashier, both for the Co-op and Waring and Gillow furniture shop in Edinburgh.Peter was a miner from the age of , working up to the role of pit depute until the pits at Monktonhall closed down in the late s. He was then a postman in Tranent for  years.The couple met at the dancing in Elphinstone and began courting not long after.They married on March , , at the Wishart St Andrewrsquos Church on Church Street in Tranent nine months later, they welcomed their first child, daughter Jacqueline, who joked that she was ldquoa honeymoon baby.Three years later, they welcomed their second child, Denise, born in July .When they married, the couple moved into their house on Main Street in Elphinstone ndash and have lived there ever since.Peter and Helen used to love going on holidays together and regularly attend Elphinstone Minersrsquo Welfare and Social Club ndash when the club opened in December , the couple couldnrsquot attend its launch as Helen was in labour with Jacqueline at the time it is the only club event they have ever missed.Peter was a keen bowler and is a lelong Hibernian FC supporter.Helen, who had a hip replacement last year, now enjoys completing puzzles such as crosswords and word searches.They are also keen gardeners and are very family-minded people who love spending time with those close to them.Despite not being able to have a party due to coronavirus regulations, Peter and Helen enjoyed their day, with the card they received from Her Majesty the Queen taking pride of place in their house and the cake Denise ordered for them also going down a treat.Jacqueline said: ldquoIt is such a great achievement. I am glad they were able to have even a wee bit of a celebration.

title: tranent-nurse-donating-hundreds-easter-eggs-elderly-people
story: Motayo Badamas, from the Windygoul area of Tranent, who has worked as a nurse for NHS Lothian for  years, set up RB Senior Care Solutions.As well as private care, including for those with complex needs, Motayo and her team offer services such as medication prompting, a tuck-in service, befriending services and hospital escorts. She has  clients, with  on her waiting list.Her company is named after her two children, Reece and Brooke.Just before and during the first lockdown last year, the company offered to pick up shopping for the elderly and infirm every Friday, free of charge.Motayorsquos company also works with East Lothian Council as a provider.She left her full-time position with the NHS last September but still works as part of NHS Lothianrsquos staff bank, similar to agency work.Earlier this month, she spoke to an elderly lady who had been on her own for nearly eight years after her husband died and her family moved away.Motayo bought her a Creme Egg as a gt.She then spoke to other clients who were in a similar situation and decided to help them out and donate them an Easter egg, appealing to the public for donations.Since making an appeal for donations on her Facebook page, Motayo has been inundated with more than  Easter eggs which she will hand out to care homes and clients her and her staff care for.The mum-of-two said: ldquoIt was heartbreaking [during the height of the pandemic], people were just passing away and passing away on their own."After speaking to some clients, I couldnrsquot believe how many people had not had an Easter egg. I want to help our community and give something back to our elderly population.On the reaction to her appeal, she said: ldquoThe community have been amazing and people have been handing in so many eggs and even money donations. Morrisons and Asda have even contacted me to askthey can donate some eggs too.ldquoIrsquom thinking of getting an Easter bunny to help me hand them out, waving from the window.The eggs will be handed out on Easter Sunday or as close to that date as possible, which this year is April  .Those who wish to make a donation towards Motayorsquos Easter egg appeal can visit facebook RBSeniorCare

title: new-use-planned-former-mens-club-haddington
story: The former Haddington Recreation Club, on the townrsquos Sidegate, closed its doors more than  years ago.Now, plans are with East Lothian Council which would see new le breathed into the building.East Lothian Property has included a supporting statement alongside ious drawings.It notes: ldquoThe property housed the Haddington Recreation Club for many years and its current use is a house in multiple occupation with four bedsits housed within the house approved in .ldquoIt is landlocked by the Brewery Court development to the north and private garden ground to the south and east.Under the plans, the ground floor of the three-storey building would become an office. Upstairs, a two-bedroom property would be created on the first and second floors.The developer notes: ldquoWe are keen to preserve this historic building forming an important part of the Haddington townscape.ldquoOur proposals will provide a viable way to maintain and preserve this historic property.Previously, planning permission was given for the creation of an office and four flats.Now, the developer has submitted fresh plans for the venue, which previously housed billiards, draughts and table tennis.

title: groups-team-provide-home-cooked-frozen-meals-need-haddington
story: Our Community Kitchen and Lammermuir Larder have teamed up to provide home-cooked frozen meals for people in the community.Volunteers at Our Community Kitchen, which was set up to tackle social isolation, have provided a selection of home-cooked meals.Chicken curry, fish pie, lasagne, cottage pie and chicken casserole are all on the menu and will be supplied to people using Lammermuir Larder.The Bridge Centre-based group was set up at the beginning of February with a view to supporting people who find themselves in crisis or financial dficulties.Food packages can be sent to people who are referred to the scheme, with volunteers working hard to set up a number of partnerships with other local groups.The latest step is to provide frozen meals for people who do not have cooking facilities.Linda Mitchell, volunteer co-ordinator, was delighted with the success of the partnership.She said: ldquoWhen the Lammermuir Larder launched in February, we offered meat vouchers for our local butcher Kevin Watt.ldquoWe wanted to offer people who liked to cook the option of fresh meat as well as the canned goods we deliver.ldquoWe are in the process of producing recipes to help and encourage cooking.ldquoIn April, we will be providing laminated recipe cards which will build into a book. They will go out weekly with deliveries.ldquoVery quickly it became apparent that there were people who had situations where they couldnrsquot cook, perhaps having become homeless, so how could they feed themselves ldquoWe approached Our Community Kitchen to discuss providing home-cooked frozen meals they were delighted to support us in this initiative.ldquoSo we took delivery of the meals at the start of March and we are now supplying them to the people we support.ldquoThis was a great opportunity for a local charity and a community group to work together to support local people.Elaine Gale, founder of Our Community Kitchen, was delighted to help.She told the Courier that  meals had already been prepared and were ready to be sent out.She said: ldquoIt is a pleasure to be doing this. We are helping our local community by doing this and we do fresh food so it seemed to make a lot of sense.ldquoThere seems to be quite a few people out there who are struggling financially.It is not the only partnership struck up by Lammermuir Larder.The group is also working with Roots and Fruits to offer people fresh fruit and vegetables.Mrs Mitchell added: ldquoTo ensure everyone we support has the chance to improve their diet, last week we began including fresh fruit in orders as we move into warmer weather, we hope to include salad vegetables.For more information, email team@lammermuirlarder or search for Our Community Kitchen on Facebook.

title: speed-checks-take-place-west-road-haddington

title: 63-000-boost-dunbar-harbour-improve-safety
story: Ports and harbours from Eyemouth to Lerwick have received a share of a pound. million Scottish Government fund.The money, which was announced ahead of the third meeting of the Scottish Seafood Exports Taskforce, has been granted to ious ports and harbours that have lost income from landing fees ldquodue to the disruption caused by Brexit, according to the Scottish Government.Dunbar Harbour Trust has received pound,, which will go towards the installation of safety rails and bridge work.Alasdair Swan, chairman of Dunbar Harbour Trust, which manages the harbour, said that the money would be split between three schemes, including improving the moorings within Cromwell Harbour and ensuring the harbour bridge could remain operational while cylinders were replaced.He said: ldquoIt is great to get that support from the Scottish Government.ldquoIt is much appreciated.ldquoThere is one railing up already at the harbour but they are rails to prevent vehicles and forklt trucks from falling in the harbour but also they are rope rails so they are useful for the boats coming into moor to tie up to them.Fergus Ewing MSP, Cabinet Secretary for Rural Economy and Tourism, described ports and harbours as ldquothe leblood of many of our coastal communities.He said: ldquoAs a result of the botched Brexit deal and through no fault of their own, many are losing key landing fees from vessels and need this essential investment.ldquoPreviously we committed pound million but I am pleased to be able to increase this to pound. million so we can provide even more funding to approximately  ports and harbours and support jobs and livelihoods in our coastal communities.ldquoWersquove been working closely with the British Ports Association on this support and the ports and harbours will be able to start essential works immediately.

title: elphinstone-primary-schools-reading-project-gets-3-000-boost
story: Elphinstone Primary School is host to one of  Scottish school library services benefiting from the Governmentrsquos School Library Improvement Fund , introduced in .This year, the grant scheme, totalling pound, and administered by the Scottish Library and Information Council , is prioritising projects aimed at supporting school library service provision for pupils during the Covid- lockdown and periods of remote learning.Elphinstone was awarded its funding for a project called lsquoElphy Talesrsquo, which aims to encourage a passion for reading. The project will involve author and Courier columnist Tim Porteus running writing workshops, linking storytelling to creative writing. Tim will also deliver staff training to help build a programme of storytelling and creative writing for the literacy curriculum.Tim said: ldquoWe decided that there was a need to be creative in the current circumstances and so I have told stories and given riddle challenges for the children on YouTube films, which have then been shared in Google Classroom by teachers.ldquoThe aim is that, with the help and support of their teachers and carers, the children can explore their own interests and creativity through storytelling.Melanie Collier, principal teacher at Elphinstone Primary School, said: ldquoFor many families, this second lockdown has been extremely dficult and many of our parents have said: lsquoMy child children have really enjoyed listening to Timrsquos stories as well as having their ideas requests of stories being brought to le by Tim.rsquoldquoOne of our parents also said: lsquoHaving the daily riddles really helped my child get up in the morning, as they were excited to see what the new daily riddle would be. It helped motivate them to get started with the rest of the daily learning tasks.rsquoldquoHaving Tim has really helped create a new, exciting dynamic to our remote learning classroom.

title: new-manager-deep-end-musselburgh-sports-centre-reopens-next-month
story: Sports centre in East Lothian are set to reopen to the public from Monday, April .And at Musselburgh, Martin Cameron, former assistant manager at Dunbar Leisure Pool, has succeeded Robert Ferguson, who has moved on after a career in the leisure industry spanning just shy of  years, firstly with East Lothian Council then with enjoyleisure, which runs sports centres on behalf of the council.Mr Ferguson has been in charge at Musselburgh Sports Centre for the past  years.Mr Cameron has spent the last  years within East Lothianrsquos leisure services. He first joined East Lothian Councilrsquos SportsPlus team in  as a relief leisure assistant at Aubigny Sports Centre, Haddington, after leaving Knox Academy. A few months later, he secured a permanent position at Dunbar Leisure Pool.Since then, he has qualied as a Learn to Swim teacher, achieved his Pool Plant certication, become a pool leguard trainer assessor and additionally a BodyPump and Spin-Fit fitness instructor.In , he was promoted to assistant service manager at Dunbar Leisure Pool and since then has played a pivotal role in the running and daily operations of the venue.Mr Cameron said: "The Musselburgh team is already taking all of the necessary steps to prepare and safeguard the centre, ready to reopen from April ."We canrsquot wait to welcome the community back to enjoy sport, fitness and leisure in East Lothian."Bill Axon, chief executive of enjoyleisure, added: "We are thrilled that Martin will be taking over the role as service manager for Musselburgh."As a long-standing employee, we have witnessed Martins progress throughout this career since joining the team in ."It is always an exceptional joy to witness a colleague so enthusiastic about the industry continuously learn, enhance and refine their knowledge and subsequently progress their career as a result of the training and learning opportunities offered to them as an employee."

title: east-lothian-residents-ballencrieff-mungoswells-dirleton-go-day-without-power
story: Power at Ballencrieff, Mungoswells and Dirleton is said to have gone out at am, with some homes yet to have power restored.SP Energy Networks said that it only became aware of the issue at .am and that it ldquodid not know in advance there would be a power cut.Those at Mungoswells with the postcodes EH PJ, EH AT, EH AU, EH AX and EH AY are expected to have their power back on by pm.A spokesperson for SP Energy Networks said: ldquoRepairs are taking longer than expected because of repairs required to a grounded overhead electricity line near Ballencrieff Mains and our team are now working to get your power back on as quickly and as safely as possible by pm.ldquoWe apologise for the inconvenience and thank you for your patience.Power to residents in Dirleton was expected to have ed by pm.The spokesperson added: ldquoWe did not know in advance there would be a power cut and are working to get supplies restored.ldquoOur team has managed to restore power to a number of properties in the area and are still working to repair the fault on our underground cable network and we now expect your supply to be restored by pm.ldquoWe understand that being without power is frustrating and please be assured we will restore your supply as soon as we possibly can.ldquoWe apologise for the inconvenience and thank you for your patience.Those at Ballencrieff saw their power restored earlier this afternoon.Johnston Craig, a Dirleton resident, said: ldquoThis is the second cut in three weeks. It was off for five hours on the evening of March . That was also a windy day but I dont knowthats the problem.ldquoWe get more than our fair share of cuts in Dirleton. Im now retired so it didnt affect me personally but my we and my neighbour couldnt work so there must be others.ldquoIts so frustrating because the estimates for it towere am, .am, pm, pm and then pm. If the estimate had been accurate to start with then perhaps other arrangements could have been taken. Im sure people with young children would agree with this point too.The Courier has contacted SP Energy Networks for comment.
